| nationalteam-update = }} '''Glenn Murray''' (born 25 September 1983) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[forward (association football)|striker]] for {{English football updater|Brigh&HA}} club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].
Prior to joining Brighton for a second spell in January 2017, Murray previously played for [[Workington A.F.C.|Workington Reds]], [[Wilmington Hammerheads FC|Wilmington Hammerheads]], [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]], [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]], [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]], [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]], [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] and [[AFC Bournemouth]].
He holds the record for most goals scored in a Championship season with 30 goals in the 2012–13 season.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.statbunker.com/alltimestats/MostGoalsScorerInSeason?comp_code=EC |title=Most goals in a season (Player) English Championship |website=Statbunker.com |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==Career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Maryport]], Cumbria,<ref name=Hugman1011/> Murray began his playing career playing for non-League side [[Workington A.F.C.|Workington Reds]] before joining American team [[Wilmington Hammerheads FC|Wilmington Hammerheads]] in 2004. He spent one season with the [[North Carolina]] club playing 14 times and scoring three goals in the [[USL Professional League]].<ref name="Wilmington Hammerheads"/> After his time in America he joined [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]] where he scored seven goals in seven games.<ref name="2004-05"/> Murray then signed for [[Conference Premier|Conference National]] side [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] and was part of the [[2005 Conference National play-off Final|Conference play-off]]-winning team in 2005 and [[Football League Two|League Two]]-winning side a season later.<ref name=2005PO>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/4537061.stm |title=Stevenage 0–1 Carlisle |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2005 |accessdate=3 December 2018}}</ref><ref name=Hugman0708>{{cite book |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2007–08 |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |publisher=Mainstream |date=2007 |page=291 |isbn=978-1-84596-246-3}}</ref>
Murray joined [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] on loan for two months and he returned to Carlisle after this loan deal, following teammate [[Karl Hawley]]'s rib injury.
===Rochdale=== [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] manager [[Steve Parkin]] then signed Murray on loan until January 2007. Murray then signed for the club on a contract until 2009, for an undisclosed fee. He made his first start for Rochdale in their 7–1 defeat away at [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] on 21 October 2006. His first goal was a 59th-minute equaliser in their match with [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] on 18 November, but Rochdale lost the match 3–2. Murray made 31 league appearances in his first season with the club and scored 16 goals.
Murray made his first appearance for the 2007–08 season as a 53rd-minute substitute on the opening day in Rochdale's 3–0 loss away to [[Peterborough United]]. His first start of the season came in their 2–2 home draw with [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the first round of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] three days later on 14 August. Murray scored his first goal of the season in a 1–1 home draw with [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the League Cup second round, and his first league goal of the season came in Rochdale's 4–3 victory away at [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] on 29 September. He made 42 league appearances scoring 21 goals, giving him an average of one goal every two games in his Rochdale career.
===Brighton & Hove Albion=== [[File:Glenn Murray Brighton.jpg|thumb|150px|Murray playing for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in 2011]]
====2007–08 season==== Murray had been linked with a transfer to [[Football League One|League One]] team [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] throughout the January [[transfer window]], and finally completed his move to the [[Withdean Stadium]] on 25 January 2008 for a reported £300,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/1995123.albion_complete_murray_signing/ |title=Albion complete Murray signing |first=Andy |last=Naylor |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=25 January 2008 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He made his debut four days later, coming on as a 61st-minute substitute for [[Nathan Elder]] during the 1–0 defeat away to [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10433~39032,00.html |title=Northampton vs Brighton |first=Tim |last=Dudding |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=29 January 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> He started Albion's next match, on 2 February at home to [[Crewe Alexandra]], and scored two goals on his home debut in the 3–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.seagulls.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10433~1231458,00.html |title=Brighton vs Crewe |first=Tim |last=Dudding |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=2 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206134955/http://www.seagulls.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10433~1231458,00.html |archivedate=6 February 2008}}</ref> Murray scored nine goals for Brighton during the 2007–08 season.
====2008–09 season==== Despite suffering several injuries during the 2008–09 season,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/3792312.albion-are-missing-murray/ |title=Albion are missing Murray |first=Andy |last=Naylor |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=27 October 2008 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/4140997.albion-striker-has-hernia-operation/ |title=Albion striker has hernia operation |first=Andy |last=Naylor |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=20 February 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray made 28 appearances and scored 12 goals.<ref name=sb0809/> In the team's 4–0 win over Barnet in the first round of the League Cup on 12 August 2008, he was sent off.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7541869.stm |title=Brighton 4–0 Barnet |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> On 27 September, he netted twice in a 2–2 draw at Northampton Town; his second put the team ahead in added time before [[Adebayo Akinfenwa]] equalised.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7626774.stm |title=Northampton 2–2 Brighton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> A week later he scored twice in the opening seven minutes and finished with his first [[hat-trick (association football)|hat-trick]] for the team in a 3–3 draw with [[Cheltenham Town]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7639353.stm |title=Brighton 3–3 Cheltenham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 October 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref>
====2009–10 season==== On 17 October 2009, Murray won and converted a penalty for a consolation goal in a 2–1 defeat at [[Tranmere Rovers]], but three minutes later was sent off for a second yellow card.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/tranmere-vs-brighton/report/110426 |title=Vital victory for Tranmere |publisher=Sky Sports |date=17 October 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored four times in Brighton's 5–2 win away at [[Wycombe Wanderers]] on 28 December, a result which moved Brighton out of the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8419150.stm |title=Wycombe 2–5 Brighton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray's season ended on 24 April 2010 with Brighton's 2–1 win over [[Bristol Rovers]] to stay in the division; he was sent off ten minutes after coming on as a substitute for [[Chris Holroyd]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8620686.stm |title=Brighton 2–1 Bristol Rovers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2010 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref>
====2010–11 season==== The 2010–11 season proved to be Murray's best season thus far at Brighton, scoring 22 goals and finishing runner-up to [[Craig Mackail-Smith]] as League One top scorer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/DivisionalScorers/0,,10794~201025,00.html |title=Football League Statistics: 2010/11 npower Football League 1 Leading scorers |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413202409/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/DivisionalScorers/0,,10794~201025,00.html |archivedate=13 April 2014}}</ref> This included a hat-trick on 1 January 2011 in a 5–0 win over [[Leyton Orient]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9310093.stm |title=Brighton 5–0 Leyton Orient |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> On 20 May, the club confirmed that Murray had rejected their final offer of a new contract, so would be available on a free transfer when his contract expired.<ref name=L1Title1011>{{cite web |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0,,10433~2363537,00.html |title=Murray's future lies away from Albion |first=Paul |last=Camillin |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523144920/http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0,,10433~2363537,00.html |archivedate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== [[File:Glenn Murray Crystal Palace.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Murray playing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2012]]
====2011–12 season==== On 24 May 2011, Murray signed a three-year contract with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], [[M23 derby|Brighton's local rivals]]. Manager [[Dougie Freedman]] said that Murray was the type of player that his squad needed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/9495783.stm |title=Crystal Palace swoop for Brighton striker Glenn Murray |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 May 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref>
He made his debut{{snd}}his first match in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]]{{snd}}in the starting eleven as Palace began the season with a 2–1 loss at [[Peterborough United]] on 6 August.<ref name=sb1112/> He scored his first goal 21 days later, the equaliser in a 1–1 draw against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/27/crystal-palace-blackpool-championship |title=Glenn Murray rescues a point for Crystal Palace against Blackpool |first=Jonny |last=Weeks |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=27 August 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> On 27 September, he netted as Palace won 3–1 at his former club Brighton.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14982392 |title=Brighton 1–3 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2011 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray scored the extra-time winner at [[Old Trafford]] against [[Manchester United]] in the League Cup quarter-finals on 30 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/15850177 |title=Manchester United 1–2 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== On 22 September 2012, Murray scored a hat-trick including two penalties against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19614999 |title=Crystal Palace 3–2 Cardiff |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> and repeated the feat on 6 November against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in a 5–0 victory despite missing a third penalty.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/c-palace-vs-ipswich/report/262516 |title=Ian Holloway in dreamland as Crystal Palace go top with 5–0 victory over Ipswich |publisher=Sky Sports |date=6 November 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored twice in a 3–0 home win over Brighton on 1 December, a result which put Palace on top of the league table.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/c-palace-vs-brighton/report/262399 |title=Glenn Murray scores twice as Crystal Palace beat Brighton 3–0 to return to top of Championship |publisher=Sky Sports |date=1 December 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
On 2 February 2013, Murray scored twice in four minutes against South London rivals [[Charlton Athletic]] as Palace came from behind to win 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/c-palace-vs-charlton/report/262499 |title=Glenn Murray scored late double as Crystal Palace beat Charlton 2–1 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 February 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> In March, he lost out to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]'s [[Matěj Vydra]] as [[EFL Awards#2013 Awards|Championship Player of the Season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21922979 |title=Football League Awards: Matej Vydra named Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 March 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 28 March, Murray signed a new three-year contract with Crystal Palace.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21966635 |title=Glenn Murray: Crystal Palace striker agrees new contract |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 March 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray missed the [[2013 Football League Championship play-off Final|play-off final]], in which Palace secured promotion to the [[Premier League]], having suffered a serious knee injury in the semi-final against Brighton.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/football-league/crystal-palace-0-brighton-0-match-report-glenn-murray-injury-blow-as-palace-draw-a-blank-in-8611871.html |title=Crystal Palace 0 Brighton 0 match report: Glenn Murray injury blow as Palace draw a blank in Championship Play-off |first=Jack |last=Pitt-Brooke |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=11 May 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== Murray came back from injury as a 72nd-minute substitute for [[Jason Puncheon]] on 8 February 2014 in a 3–1 home win against [[West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/feb/08/crystal-palace-west-bromwich-albion-premier-league-match-report |title=Crystal Palace new boy Tom Ince inspires victory over West Brom |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=8 February 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 2 March, he scored his only goal of the season and his first in the Premier League, winning a late penalty against Swansea City after being fouled by [[Chico Flores]] and converting it past [[Michel Vorm]] to earn a 1–1 away draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26311677 |title=Swansea City 1–1 Crystal Palace |first=Rob |last=Westall |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 March 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== ====Reading (loan)==== On 1 September 2014, transfer deadline day, Murray moved to Championship club [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on loan until 1 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/2014/september/deadline-deal-striker-murray-signs-for-royals/ |title=Deadline deal: Striker Murray signs for Royals |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=1 September 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored twice in his debut match in a 3–0 win over Fulham.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29091163 |title=Reading 3–0 Fulham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray scored eight goals in 18 league games for Reading, ending on 26 December with a brace in a 2–2 draw at Brighton where he opened the scoring after 39 seconds.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/reading-fc-manager-steve-clarke-8349277 |title=Reading FC manager Steve Clarke content with a point after draw with Brighton & Hove Albion |first=Jonathan |last=Low |website=GetReading |date=27 December 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====Return to Palace==== At the end of January 2015, Murray signed a contract extension with Palace until 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/january/murray-signs-contract-extension/ |title=Murray signs contract extension |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2015}}</ref> On 28 February, he scored twice and was sent off for two bookings as Palace won 3–1 away to West Ham United.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31562853 |title=West Ham United 1–3 Crystal Palace |first=Simon |last=Stone |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 February 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray opened the scoring as Palace defeated reigning Premier League champions [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 2–1 on 6 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32111603 |title=Crystal Palace 2–1 Manchester City |first=Jonathan |last=Smith |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 April 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray continued his goalscoring form by giving Palace a 1–0 lead in their 4–1 win at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 11 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32180018 |title=Sunderland 1–4 Crystal Palace |first=Michael |last=Emons |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 April 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Eight days later, Murray was selected in the [[Football League Awards#2015 Awards|Football Manager Team of the Decade]] at the [[Football League Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2015/april/winners-announced-at-the-football-league-awards-2015/ |title=Winners announced at The Football League Awards 2015 |publisher=The Football League |date=20 April 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 16 May against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], in [[Steven Gerrard]]'s final match at [[Anfield]], Murray's penalty was saved by [[Simon Mignolet]] but he hit in the rebound to confirm a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32670817 |title=Liverpool 1–3 Crystal Palace |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 7 August 2015, Crystal Palace rejected a £3 million bid for Murray from Premier League rivals [[AFC Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/07/crystal-palace-bournemouth-glenn-murray |title=Crystal Palace reject £3m bid from Bournemouth for Glenn Murray |first=Ed |last=Aarons |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=7 August 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 1 September, an improved bid of £4 million was accepted, and Murray joined the club on a three-year-deal.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/34110604 |title=Glenn Murray: Bournemouth sign Crystal Palace striker for £4m |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Bournemouth on 3 October in a 1–1 draw with Watford, a fellow newly promoted team, but had a penalty saved late on.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34366697 |title=AFC Bournemouth 1–1 Watford |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 October 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored a consolation goal in the following match, a 5–1 loss at Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34493635 |title=Manchester City 5–1 AFC Bournemouth |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 October 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> In December, he scored a late headed goal to clinch a win against reigning champions [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34951749 |title=Chelsea 0–1 AFC Bournemouth |first=Richard |last=Winton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 December 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
===Return to Brighton=== On 3 July 2016, Murray returned to Brighton & Hove Albion on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2016/july/murray-back-at-brighton/ |title=Murray back at Brighton |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=3 July 2016 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> His second debut for the Sussex side came on 6 August away to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], while his first goal in his second spell came at home to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] six days later; he scored his second in the same match as Albion won 3–0.<ref name=sb1617/> Brighton repeated that scoreline at [[Falmer Stadium]] four days later against [[Rotherham United]], and Murray was again on the scoresheet.<ref name=sb1617/> On 29 October, Murray scored a hat-trick against Norwich City at Falmer as the Seagulls secured a 5–0 win,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2016/october/albion-v-norwich/ |title=Albion v Norwich |first=James |last=Hilsum |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=29 October 2016 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> and on 18 November he scored his 150th career League goal in a 1–1 draw with [[Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/18/brighton-aston-villa-championship-match-report |title=Glenn Murray landmark league strike earns Brighton point against Aston Villa |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=18 November 2016 |accessdate=18 November 2016}}</ref>
On 31 January 2017, Murray re-signed permanently for Brighton & Hove Albion on a deal until June 2019. He had scored 15 goals in 28 appearances while on loan to the club in the first half of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/soccer-transfers/story/3050297/brighton-sign-glenn-murray-on-permanent-deal-from-bournemouth |title=Brighton sign Glenn Murray on permanent deal from Bournemouth |publisher=ESPN |agency=PA Sport |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He contributed 8 more league goals in the remainder of the season, including the opening goal in a 2–1 home win against [[Wigan Athletic]] on 17 April that sealed Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in their history.<ref name=sb1617/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39549523 |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2–1 Wigan Athletic |first=Gary |last=Smee |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 April 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
Newly promoted Brighton made a positive start to their inaugural Premier League season, sitting in 8th place after eleven games. An unbeaten run of four games from mid-October coincided with Murray hitting a good run of form, with the striker scoring four goals in the three games preceding the November international break. His scoring run began with two against West Ham United in a 3–0 away win, and he followed it up with goals against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at home and Swansea City away, earning Brighton four points.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/swansea-0-brighton-1-match-report-glenn-murray-goal-watch-replay-table-a8037831.html |title=Glenn Murray's goal-streak continues as Brighton battle past Swansea |first=Phil |last=Blanche |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=4 November 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 8 January 2018, Murray scored the winning goal in Brighton's 2–1 victory over arch rivals and former club Crystal Palace to eliminate them from the [[FA Cup]] at the third-round stage.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jan/08/brighton-hove-albion-crystal-palace-fa-cup-third-round-match-report |title=Glenn Murray leaves it late as Brighton knock Crystal Palace out of FA Cup |first=David |last=Hytner |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=8 January 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
On 1 September 2018 Murray scored twice to take Brighton from 2–0 down to draw 2–2 with Fulham.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45305232 |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2–2 Fulham |first=Steve |last=Sutcliffe |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> His 100th goal for Albion, the only goal of the match at home to [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 27 October, made him just the second man{{snd}}after [[Tommy Cook (sportsman)|Tommy Cook]] with 123{{snd}}to reach that milestone.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/matches/fixtures/first-team/2018192/october/brighton-and-hove-albion-vs-wolverhampton-wanderers-on-27-oct-18/ |title=Report: Albion 1 Wolves 0 |first=James |last=Hilsum |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=27 October 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> After 9 games without scoring, on 29 January 2019 Murray scored another two goals against Fulham in a 4-2 away defeat. This time Fulham came back from 2 goals behind, and won.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46955255 |title=Fulham V Brighton & Hove Albion|publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 January 2019 |accessdate=29 January 2019}}</ref> On 6 February 2019 Murray scored another two goals this time coming off the bench in a fourth round FA Cup replay against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] where his goals put Brighton 2-1 and 3-1 up in the 3-1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/av/football/47151469|title=FA Cup: West Bromwich Albion 1-3 Brighton & Hove Albion highlights - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport|date= 6 February 2019|accessdate= 6 February 2019}}</ref> On 9 March 2019 Murray scored his 100th league goal for The Seagulls at his former club and bitter rivals Crystal Palace in a 2-1 away victory. This win meant Brighton won the double over Palace.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47424852|title=Crystal Palace V Brighton & Hove Albion - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport|date= 9 March 2019|accessdate= 9 March 2019}}</ref>
==Personal life== On 24 January 2018, Murray and his wife Stacey were arrested on suspicion of tax fraud totalling £1.1 million.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42809696 |title=Glenn Murray: Brighton striker arrested over £1.1m tax fraud |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 January 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/01/24/glenn-murray-wife-arrested-connection-suspected-11m-tax-fraud/ |title=Glenn Murray and wife arrested in connection with suspected £1.1m tax fraud |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=24 January 2018 |accessdate=25 January 2018}}</ref>

nationalyears2 = 2014–2017 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 3 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | club-update = 14:30, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Solomon Benjamin March''' (born 20 July 1994) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|Brigh&HA}} club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].
==Early life== March was born in [[Eastbourne]], East Sussex. His father, Steve, had been an apprentice footballer at [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in the late 1980s.<ref name="auto">{{cite news |last=Griggs |first=Howard |url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/9376461.Seagulls_swoop_for_Lewes_starlet/ |title=Seagulls swoop for Lewes starlet |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=22 November 2011 |accessdate=5 September 2018}}</ref> March attended secondary school at [[Ringmer Community College]] and [[St Bede's School, Eastbourne|St Bede's School]], [[Hailsham]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bedes.org/alumni/news/news/2015/2015/06/solly-march-training-with-tony-morriss.aspx |title=Alumni: Bede's welcomes returning footballer Solomon March |first=Caroline |last=Harms |publisher=Bede's |date=26 June 2015 |accessdate=5 September 2018}}</ref> Between 2008 and 2012 March played cricket for Hellingly C.C.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bwmcc.play-cricket.com/website/player_stats_widget/batting_stats/265064?rule_type_id=179|title=Barnsley Woolley Miners CC|website=bwmcc.play-cricket.com}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Lewes=== March played at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] between the ages of 11 and 13 and then switched from [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]] to fellow East Sussex club [[Lewes F.C.|Lewes]] as a youth player.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eastsussex.gov.uk/media/7925/your-county-spring-2017-ebook.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=25 August 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825232505/https://www.eastsussex.gov.uk/media/7925/your-county-spring-2017-ebook.pdf |archivedate=25 August 2017 }}</ref><ref name="Solly March Report"/> Lewes were playing in the [[Isthmian League]] Premier Division, and the 17-year-old March made his first-team debut on 10 September 2011, coming on in the 86th minute as a substitute against [[Aveley F.C.|Aveley]],<ref name=LewesDebut>{{cite magazine |url=https://en.calameo.com/read/00000375303f7a57d3f4d |title=Match report Lewes 4:1 Aveley |first=Tom |last=Harper |magazine=The Rooks |publisher=Lewes F.C. |page=13 |date=24 September 2011 |via=Calaméo}}</ref> when he was offered a scholarship by Brighton & Hove Albion.<ref name="auto"/>
===Brighton & Hove Albion=== ===Early days at Brighton=== March signed a three-year contract with Brighton in December 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11741/7344289/seagulls-seal-non-league-swoop|title=Seagulls seal non-league swoop}}</ref> At the time of his transfer it was reported by the Brighton [[The Argus (Brighton)|Argus]] that March had also been offered a contract with [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] and a trial with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion snatched Solly March from under the nose of Newcastle|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15107798.Albion_snatched_March_from_under_the_nose_of_Newcastle/|publisher=The Argus|date=22 February 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Lewes manager Steve King suggested that March had been attracted to Brighton because of the style of football they were playing under manager [[Gus Poyet]] and because the move to another East Sussex club would allow him to remain close to his family.<ref name="auto"/>
While progressing through Brighton's youth squad, March quickly made an impact for the side and scored a hat–trick, in a 3–1 win over [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]]'s youth squad on 18 February 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=March treble wins it for kids|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/9540044.March_treble_wins_it_for_kids/|publisher=The Argus|date=18 February 2012|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> While still a member of Brighton's development squad, 2013 saw the beginning of March's senior career. During the last half of the 2012–13 season, March made the bench for three senior Championship games but did not make an appearance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion make two changes|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10115587.Albion_make_two_changes/|publisher=The Argus|date=18 December 2012|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March impressed in Brighton's youth squad, earning himself the team's Young Player of the Year Award 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2013/may/bridcutt-named-player-of-the-year/|title=Bridcutt Named Player of the Year|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|date=7 May 2013|accessdate=18 August 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817194852/https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2013/may/bridcutt-named-player-of-the-year/|archivedate=17 August 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> and a contract extension until 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/albion/10433845.Four_youngsters_handed_new_deals/ |title=Four youngsters handed new deals (From The Argus) |publisher=Theargus.co.uk |date=21 May 2013 |accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref>
===2013–14=== He then performed well in pre-season friendlies with the first team prior to the start of the 2013–14 season; highlighted with a 'superb' goal against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Owen|first=Brian|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10581198.March_strike_gives_Albion_a_draw/|title=March strike gives Albion a draw (From The Argus)|publisher=The Argus|date=30 July 2013|accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref> March was a named substitute in five of the first six games in the 2013–14 season and was substituted on in the 85th and 91st minutes against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] and [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] respectively,<ref>{{cite news|title=Solly on the March for Albion|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10785667.Solly_on_the_March_for_Albion/|publisher=The Argus|date=6 November 2013|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> thus creating his debut in Brighton's first team. Around November, March's first team opportunities became limited, leading to rumours that he's expected to be loaned out.<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion prospect could go out on loan|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10833878.Albion_prospect_could_go_out_on_loan/|publisher=The Argus|date=26 November 2013|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> However, the move never happened and he stayed at the club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion prospect stays|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/10842933.Albion_prospect_stays/|publisher=The Argus|date=28 November 2013|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Despite this, March scored his first senior goal for the Albion in an FA Cup fourth round tie at [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] on 25 January 2014. The game also saw [[Rohan Ince]] and [[Jon Obika]] score their first goals for the club in a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news|title=Port Vale 1 – 3 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25789219|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 January 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> For the rest of the season, March was given a handful of first team opportunities, resulting him making 28 appearances in all competitions.<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion youngster surprised by rapid progress|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11006326.Albion_youngster_surprised_by_rapid_progress/|publisher=The Argus|date=13 February 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Solly can march on for Seagulls|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11019617.Solly_can_march_on_for_Seagulls/|publisher=The Argus|date=19 February 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=March starts, Mackail-Smith on bench|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11129435.March_starts__Mackail_Smith_on_bench/|publisher=The Argus|date=5 April 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Because of this, March signed a new four-year deal with the ''Seagulls'' in April 2014.<ref>{{Cite web |title=March Buzzing Over Future|url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/news/article/solly-march-buzzing-at-long-term-brighton-hove-albion-future-1486668.aspx|work=Brighton & Hove Albion FC |date=14 April 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415120436/http://www.seagulls.co.uk/news/article/solly-march-buzzing-at-long-term-brighton-hove-albion-future-1486668.aspx|archivedate=15 April 2014|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
===2014–15=== [[File:Solomon March bha-2014.jpg|thumb|upright|March playing for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in 2014 against former club Lewes in a pre season friendly. ]]
To begin the 2014–15 season, March worked on improving his match fitness.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fenelon starts as Albion hand out four debuts|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11399624.Fenelon_starts_as_Albion_hand_out_four_debuts/|publisher=The Argus|date=9 August 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> However, his progress stalled as he suffered a lower back problem that would rule him out for several months.<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion concern about March injury|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11420365.Albion_concern_about_March_injury/|publisher=The Argus|date=20 August 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> After returning to training from injury,<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion keeper allowed to stay put in Middle East as Stockdale returns|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11618035.Albion_keeper_allowed_to_stay_put_in_Middle_East_as_Stockdale_returns/|publisher=The Argus|date=21 November 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March made his first appearance of the season, coming on as a second half substitute, in a 2–1 loss against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on 29 November 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1 – 2 Fulham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30155731|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 November 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> In the club's second meeting against Fulham thirty days later, on 29 December 2014, he scored his first goal of the season, in a 2–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 0 – 2 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30572357|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> This was followed up by setting up a goal for Rohan Ince, who scored the only goal of the game, in a win over [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlton Athletic 0 – 1 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30663310|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 January 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March went on to have a handful of first team appearances until February when he suffered a calf injury during a 3–2 loss against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 7 February 2015, in what turns out to be his last appearance of the season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hughton vows to look at loan market to end Albion's wing woes|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11782044.Hughton_vows_to_look_at_loan_market_to_end_Albion_s_wing_woes/|publisher=The Argus|date=10 February 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Initially out for weeks, March was eventually for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news|title=March likely to miss rest of Albion's campaign|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/12866048.March_likely_to_miss_rest_of_Albion_s_campaign/|publisher=The Argus|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=March blow for Albion as they close in on Ledesma|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11804251.March_blow_for_Albion_as_they_close_in_on_Ledesma/|publisher=The Argus|date=19 February 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Despite this, he went on to make 13 appearances and scoring once in all competitions.
===2015–16=== In the 2015–16 season, March returned to the first team from injury<ref>{{cite news|title=March targets a big year with Albion and England|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/13347209.March_targets_a_big_year_with_Albion_and_England/|publisher=The Argus|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> and started the season well when he set up a goal for [[Kazenga LuaLua]], in a 1–0 win over Nottingham Forest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1 – 0 Nottingham Forest|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33729037|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 August 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Since returning from injury, March regained his first team place at the club, mostly in the right–midfield position.<ref>{{cite news|title=March starts on the wing and Dunk is back|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/13801841.March_starts_on_the_wing_and_Dunk_is_back/|publisher=The Argus|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> He then scored his first goal of the season, in a 2–1 win over [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on 17 October 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leeds United 1 – 2 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34493178|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 October 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> He went on to score two goals later in the season against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|MK Dons]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2 – 1 Milton Keynes Dons|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34686026|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 November 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> and [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2 – 1 Birmingham City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34887113|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 November 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> His performance throughout November earned him a nomination for November's Player of the Month but lost out to [[Daryl Murphy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion duo shortlisted for November awards|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14135050.Albion_duo_shortlisted_for_November_awards/|publisher=The Argus|date=10 December 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton and Hove Albion boss Chris Hughton avoids manager of the month hoodoo|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14139474.Relief_as_Hughton_misses_out_on_manager_of_the_month_prize/|publisher=The Argus|date=11 December 2015|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> However, on 12 December 2015, March suffered a season ending knee injury during a 2–2 draw against Derby County.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35111789|title=Solly March: Brighton winger's season ended by knee injury|date=16 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Despite this, March made 17 appearances and scored three times for Brighton in the 2015–16 season.
===2016–17=== At the beginning of the 2016–17 season, March remained sidelined out of the first team since returning from a knee injury.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton and Hove Albion duo likely to miss pre-season trip|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14581103.Albion_duo_likely_to_miss_pre_season_trip/|publisher=The Argus|date=27 June 2016|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> He returned to action from injury in a reserve match against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]’s U23 side on 22 August 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton and Hove Albion winger Solly March back in action after lengthy injury|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14696764.March_makes_August_comeback_for_Albion/|publisher=The Argus|date=22 August 2016|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> After playing in the reserve side for the first few months since returning from injury,<ref>{{cite news|title=More game time for Solly March as Albion Under-23s win|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14708322.More_game_time_for_March_as_Albion_Under_23s_win/|publisher=The Argus|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March signed a contract extension with Brighton, keeping him at the club until 2020.<ref>{{cite news|title=Solly March signs long-term Brighton and Hove Albion deal|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14781586.March_signs_long_term_Albion_deal___and_closes_in_on_playing_return/|publisher=The Argus|date=4 October 2016|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March made his return to the first team on 5 November 2016, coming on as a second–half substitute in a 2–0 win over [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bristol City 0 – 2 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37807860|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 November 2016|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March then scored his first goal of the season, in a 3–3 draw against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on 5 February 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brentford 3 – 3 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38786510|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 February 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> This was followed up by setting up two goals in a 4–1 win over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 4 – 1 Burton Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38864156|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 February 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March went on to score two more goals throughout the season, against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Rotherham United 0 – 2 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39111438|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 March 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> and [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], with the Wigan goal on 17 April 2017 being the decider in Brighton's promotion.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2 – 1 Wigan Athletic|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39549523|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 April 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Since returning to the first team from injury, March began to regained his first team in the midfield position and played a key role in the side gaining promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Steve Sidwell can't wait to see Solly March in full flight|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/14986500.Sidwell_can_t_wait_to_see_March_in_full_flight/|publisher=The Argus|date=24 December 2016|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton and Hove Albion urged to give Solly March a run of games|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15101326.Keep_faith_with_Solly__Albion_urged_to_give_March_a_run/|publisher=The Argus|date=18 February 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Promotion celebration: Ten reasons why Brighton and Hove Albion are heading for the Premier League|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15284687.Promotion_celebration__Ten_reasons_why_Albion_are_heading_for_the_Premier_League/|publisher=The Argus|date=14 May 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> At the end of the 2016–17 season, March went on to make 24 appearances and scoring three times in all competitions.
===2017–18=== In the 2017–18 season, March made his Premier League debut, where he started and played for 75 minutes before being substituted, in a 2–0 loss against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 0 – 2 Manchester City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40835422|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 August 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> March scored his first Premier League goal for Brighton on 15 September 2017, the opening goal in a 2–1 away defeat to [[AFC Bournemouth]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41196761|title=AFC Bournemouth 2–1 Brighton & Hove Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 September 2017}}</ref>
===2018–19===
On 16 December 2018 March scored his 10th goal for the Albion in a 2−1 home defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in which was his first Premier League goal at [[The Amex]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46497570|title=Brighton 1-2 Chelsea: Eden Hazard stars as Blues hold on for win - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 December 2018}}</ref> On 17 March 2019, [[Jurgen Locadia]] scored in the [[2018-19 FA Cup|FA Cup]] quarter final away against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]. His goal gave Brighton a lifeline putting them just a goal behind at [[The Den]]. A few minutes later March scored a last gasp free kick making it 2–2 and to take it to extra time. The game stayed level throughout extra time and Brighton went to win on penalties 5–4 (in which Locadia and March both scored in) to take them to [[Wembley]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47512116|title=Millwall 2–2 Brighton (pens 4-5): Brighton into FA Cup semi-finals on penalties - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 March 2019}}</ref>
==International career== March was named by [[Gareth Southgate]] as a forward in the [[England national under-21 football team|England Under-21]] squad in May 2014. The squad will play a [[UEFA European Under-21 Championship|Euro U-21s]] qualification match against Wales and at least four games at the [[Toulon Tournament]]. March had not previously played for England at any level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/under-21/2014/may/squad-named-for-wales-toulon-tournament-130514 |title=England U21 squad for Wales and Toulon named |publisher=The Football Association |date=13 May 2014 }}</ref> After appearing as an unused substitute against [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales U21]] on 19 May 2014,<ref>{{cite news|title=Albion midfielder makes England debut|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11223261.Albion_midfielder_makes_England_debut/|publisher=The Argus|date=20 May 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Solly made his England under-21 debut against [[Qatar national under-20 football team|Qatar U20]] on 22 May 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Forster-Caskey on target as England start with a win|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/11231888.Forster_Caskey_on_target_as_England_start_with_a_win/|publisher=The Argus|date=22 May 2014|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> On 27 March 2017, March scored his first international goal in a U21 friendly against [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark U21]] with a strike from outside the box.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39302209 |title=Denmark U21 0–4 England U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 March 2017 |accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
==Style of play== March typically plays on the wing either in midfield or as part of a forward line. Steve King, his former manager at Lewes, described March as a "technically very good" player who "has bags of energy, is a box-to-box player, has a good left foot, a good shot, he sees things early and the weight of his passes is very good."<ref name="auto"/><ref name="Solly March Report">{{cite news|title=Scout Report: Solly March|url=http://outsideoftheboot.com/2017/05/18/scout-report-solly-march/|publisher=Outside of the Boot|date=18 May 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== In May 2017, following Brighton & Hove Albion's promotion to the Premier League, March became engaged to girlfriend Amelia Goldman after proposing to her in Dubai.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brighton and Hove Albion winger Solly March aiming to take Premier League by storm|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15277978.Albion_winger_aiming_to_take_Premier_League_by_storm/|publisher=The Argus|date=11 May 2017|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref>

nationalcaps7 = 5 | nationalgoals7 = 0 | club-update = 14:30, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 26 December 2015 }} '''Martín Montoya Torralbo''' (born 14 April 1991) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].
He started playing with [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], going on to appear in 67 competitive games during five [[La Liga]] seasons and win seven major titles (two goals scored). In the competition he also represented [[Real Betis|Betis]] and [[Valencia CF|Valencia]], totalling 112 matches and three goals all clubs combined.
==Club career== ===Barcelona=== Born in [[Gavà]], [[Province of Barcelona|Barcelona]], [[Catalonia]], Montoya started playing football for hometown club [[CF Gavà]], moving to [[FC Barcelona]]'s youth system, ''[[La Masia]]'', at the age of 8. After progressing through its ranks, he was promoted to the [[FC Barcelona B|B-team]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.abc.es/deportes/futbol/20121125/abci-barcelona-canteranos-vilanova-201211252131.html|title=El Barcelona, con once canteranos|trans-title=Barcelona, with eleven youth players|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|language=es|date=25 November 2012|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref>
In the [[2009–10 Segunda División B|2009–10 season]], Montoya contributed with 22 games as the [[Luis Enrique (footballer)|Luis Enrique]]-led side returned to the [[Segunda División|second division]] after an 11-year absence. On 26 February 2011 he made his debut for the main squad, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Adriano (footballer, born 1984)|Adriano]] in the last five minutes of a 3–0 away win against [[RCD Mallorca]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=302171&cc=5739|title=Barcelona too strong for Mallorca|publisher=[[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]]|date=26 February 2011|accessdate=27 February 2011}}</ref>
Towards the end of March 2011, rumours surfaced linking Montoya with [[Valencia CF]], who was willing to pay the €3 million buy-out clause of the player.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://goal.com/en/news/12/spain/2011/03/29/2416171/valencia-keen-on-barcelonas-martin-montoya-report|title=Valencia keen on Barcelona's Martin Montoya|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|last=Coerts|first=Stefan|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/barca/montoya-renovacion-o-al-valencia-977089|title=Montoya, ¿renovación o al Valencia?|trans-title=Montoya, renewed or to Valencia?|newspaper=[[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]]|last=San Antonio|first=Iván|language=es|date=18 April 2011|accessdate=22 January 2018}}</ref> On 30 April, he made his first start for Barcelona in a 1–2 [[La Liga]] loss at [[Real Sociedad]], suffering a broken [[clavicle]] in the early minutes of the match and being sidelined for the rest of [[2010–11 La Liga|the campaign]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1427527.html?cid=rssfeed&att=|title=Milito, Montoya out for six weeks|publisher=FIFA|date=1 May 2011|accessdate=1 May 2011}}</ref>
Montoya again spent the vast majority of [[2011–12 Segunda División|2011–12]] with the reserves. His first start for the first team occurred on 12 January 2012, in a [[2011–12 Copa del Rey|2–1 away triumph]] against [[CA Osasuna]] for the [[Copa del Rey]] (6–1 on aggregate).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/copa/octavos/vuelta/osa_bar/|title=Messi enciende las antiniebla|trans-title=Messi turns fog lamps on|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|last=Aldunate|first=Ramiro|language=es|date=13 January 2012|accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref> Due to injury to [[Dani Alves]] he played in the [[2012 Copa del Rey Final|final of the domestic cup]], featuring the full 90 minutes in a 3–0 win over [[Athletic Bilbao]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=339977&cc=5739|title=Barca say goodbye in style|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=25 May 2012|accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> he had previously scored his first official goal on 6 December 2011, helping the hosts defeat [[FC BATE Borisov]] 4–0 in [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|the group stage]] of the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/barcelona-vs-bate-borisov/249491|title=Barcelona 4–0 BATE Borisov|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=6 December 2011|accessdate=5 September 2018}}</ref>
Montoya scored his second goal as a professional on 1 June 2013, netting the third in a 4–1 home win against [[Málaga CF]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/348167/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=null|title=Barca bring up century in style|publisher=ESPN FC|date=1 June 2013|accessdate=1 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623043129/http://espnfc.com/en/report/348167/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=null|archivedate=23 June 2013|df=}}</ref> He finished [[2012–13 La Liga|the season]] with 24 appearances all competitions comprised, totalling 1,678 minutes of action.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fichajes.com/serie-a/el-inter-de-milan-ya-busca-un-relevo-para-martin-montoya_93815|title=El Inter de Milán insiste en reemplazar a Martín Montoya|trans-title=Inter Milan insist on replacing Martín Montoya|publisher=Fichajes|last=Chamorro|first=David|language=es|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref>
Montoya expressed his desire to leave the [[Camp Nou]] in December 2014, after the signing of another player for his position, also Brazilian [[Douglas (footballer, born 1990)|Douglas]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/545941/Arsenal-Liverpool-Juventus-Barcelona-Martin-Montoya-football-transfer-news|title=Juventus to scupper Arsenal and Liverpool bids for Barcelona full-back Martin Montoya|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|last=Short|first=Joe|date=10 December 2014|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/wantaway-barcelona-starlet-who-could-be-perfect-option-liverpool|title=The wantaway Barcelona starlet who could be the perfect option for Liverpool|publisher=[[FourFourTwo]]|last=Roden|first=Lee|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref> He eventually stayed until the end of [[2014–15 La Liga|the campaign]], which ended in [[Treble (association football)|treble]] conquest, his only major contribution being playing 80 minutes in a 3–1 success at [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.]] for [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|the Champions League quarter-finals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32295986|title=Paris St G 1–3 Barcelona|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Dawkes|first=Phil|date=15 April 2015|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.givemesport.com/565766-martin-montoya-is-not-good-enough-for-barcelona|title=Martin Montoya is not good enough for Barcelona|publisher=Give Me Sport|last=Pettigrove|first=Jason|date=17 April 2015|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref>
In July 2015, Montoya joined [[Inter Milan]] on a [[2015–16 Serie A|season]]-long loan for €1.3 million, with the option of extending the deal for another year pending appearances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/martin-montoya-joins-inter-milan-on-loan|title=Martín Montoya joins Inter Milan on loan|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inter.it/en/news/48528|title=Martin Montoya joins Inter|publisher=Inter Milan|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref><ref>F.C. Internazionale Milano S.p.A. ''bilancio'' (financial report and accounts) on 30 June 2015 (in Italian), [http://www.registroimprese.it PDF purchased from Italian C.C.I.A.A.]</ref> The Italian club also had an obligation to buy him for €6 million, if he played 33% of all competitive matches during his tenure and each appearance amounted to at least 30 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/martin-montoya-joins-inter-milan-on-loan|title=Martín Montoya joins Inter Milan on loan|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interlive.it/2015/10/19/inter-da-kondogbia-a-montoya-ecco-le-cifre-ufficiali-del-mercato/|title=Inter, da Kondogbia a Montoya: ecco le cifre ufficiali del mercato|trans-title=Inter, from Kondogbia to Montoya: here are the official market figures|publisher=Inter Live|date=19 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2016}}</ref>
On 1 February 2016, still owned by Barcelona, Montoya signed with [[Real Betis]] until 30 June.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/marin-montoya-loaned-to-real-betis|title=Martín Montoya loaned to Real Betis|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=1 February 2016|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref>
===Valencia=== On 1 August 2016, Montoya signed a four-year deal with Valencia following the expiration of his contract with Barcelona.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.valenciacf.com/ver/59824/martin-montoya-joins-valencia-cf.html|title=Martín Montoya joins Valencia CF|publisher=Valencia CF|date=1 August 2016|accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref> He played 29 matches<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.valenciacf.com/ver/74733/el-reencuentro-de-martin-montoya-con-el-betis.html|title=El reencuentro de Martín Montoya con el Betis|trans-title=Martín Montoya meets Betis again|publisher=Valencia CF|language=es|date=14 October 2017|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> and scored twice in [[2016–17 La Liga|his first season]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.efe.com/efe/espana/deportes/3-osasuna-y-valencia-empatan-en-un-partido-con-tres-remontadas-locales/10006-3143942|title=3–3. Osasuna y Valencia empatan en un partido con tres remontadas locales|trans-title=3–3. Osasuna and Valencia draw in match with three local comebacks|publisher=[[EFE]]|language=es|date=9 January 2017|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/espanyol/balsamica-victoria-del-valencia-costa-del-espanyol-5744413|title=Balsámica victoria del Valencia a costa del Espanyol|trans-title=Balsamic Valencia win at the expense of Espanyol|newspaper=[[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]]|last=Pi|first=Joan|language=es|date=15 January 2017|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> with his team finally ranking in 12th place.
===Brighton & Hove Albion=== On 9 August 2018, Montoya signed with English club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] for €7 million, subject to international clearance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2018/august/seagulls-swoop-for-montoya/|title=Seagulls swoop for Montoya|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> He made his debut in the [[Premier League]] ten days later, playing the full 90 minutes in a 3–2 home win against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/1004470/Brighton-Man-Utd-Live-Stream-Team-News-Score-Goals-Paul-Pogba-Jose-Mourinho-Latest|title=Brighton 3–2 Man Utd RESULT: Jose Mourinho delivers verdict after shock defeat|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|last=Anderson|first=Jamie|date=19 August 2018|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== In 2011, Montoya earned his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]] with the [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spanish under-21 team]]. He was picked by manager [[Luis Milla]] to the squad that competed in [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|that year]]'s [[UEFA European Under-21 Championship|UEFA European Championship]], and started in all the games as the national side won the tournament in Denmark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/2378/euro-u-21/2013/06/19/4053538/euro-under-21-team-of-the-tournament-thiago-isco-star-as|title=Euro Under-21 Team of the Tournament: Thiago & Isco star as Spain dominate|publisher=Goal|last=Myson|first=Chris|date=19 June 2013|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref>
On 25 August 2011, Montoya was selected for the first time to [[Spain national football team|the full side]] by coach [[Vicente del Bosque]], for games against [[Chile national football team|Chile]] and [[Liechtenstein national football team|Liechtenstein]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/08/25/futbol/seleccion/1314268980.html|title=Domínguez, Montoya y Botía, novedades de la lista de Del Bosque|trans-title=Domínguez, Montoya and Botía, news in Del Bosque's list|newspaper=Marca|last=Amaro|first=Javier|language=es|date=25 August 2011|accessdate=26 August 2011}}</ref> However, he did not take the field on either match.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/barca/martin-montoya-vuelve-con-la-sub21-1166149|title=Martín Montoya vuelve con la sub'21|trans-title=Martín Montoya returns to the under'21s|newspaper=Sport|language=es|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>

2019}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|National Cup !colspan=2|League Cup !colspan=2|Europe !colspan=2|Other
