(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]]) | clubnumber = 16 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] | years1 = 2005–2011 | clubs1 = [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] | caps1 = 49 | goals1 = 16 | years2 = 2008 | clubs2 = → [[Maccabi Herzliya F.C.|Maccabi Herzliya]] (loan) | caps2 = 17 | goals2 = 3 | years3 = 2008–2009 | clubs3 = → [[Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv F.C.|Bnei Yehuda]] (loan) | caps3 = 28 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2009–2010 | clubs4 = → [[Maccabi Ahi Nazareth F.C.|Maccabi Ahi Nazareth]] (loan) | caps4 = 33 | goals4 = 9 | years5 = 2011–2014 | clubs5 = [[RCD Mallorca|Mallorca]] | caps5 = 90 | goals5 = 20 | years6 = 2014–2015 | clubs6 = [[UD Almería|Almería]] | caps6 = 35 | goals6 = 8 | years7 = 2015– | clubs7 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps7 = 89 | goals7 = 32 | years8 = 2018– | clubs8 = → [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] (loan) | caps8 = 16 | goals8 = 5 | nationalyears1 = 2003–2004 | nationalteam1 = [[Israel national under-17 football team|Israel U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 12 | nationalgoals1 = 9 | nationalyears2 = 2005 | nationalteam2 = [[Israel national under-18 football team|Israel U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 5 | nationalyears3 = 2005–2006 | nationalteam3 = [[Israel national under-19 football team|Israel U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 22 | nationalgoals3 = 24 | nationalyears4 = 2006–2008 | nationalteam4 = [[Israel national under-21 football team|Israel U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 3 | nationalgoals4 = 3 | nationalyears5 = 2011– | nationalteam5 = [[Israel national football team|Israel]] | nationalcaps5 = 35 | nationalgoals5 = 17 | pcupdate = 16 March 2019 | ntupdate = 14 October 2018 }} '''Tomer Hemed''' ({{lang-he|תומר חמד}}; born 2 May 1987) is an [[Israel]]i professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] and plays internationally for the [[Israel national football team|Israel national team]]. ==Club career== ===Maccabi Haifa=== Hemed was called up to [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]]'s first-team in early 2006, after scoring regularly for the under-18 side. He appeared three times with the main squad, scoring once, before returning to the youth side. He made his debut in the campaign on 3 March 2007, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 1–2 home loss against [[Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv F.C.|Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv]].{{cite web|url=http://eng.football.org.il/Leagues/Pages/LeagueGameDetails.aspx?GAME_ID=113612|title=Maccabi Haifa 1–2 Hakoach Maccabi Amidar Ramat Gan|publisher=[[Israel Football Association]]|date=3 March 2007|accessdate=30 June 2014}} Hemed scored his first professional goals on 26 May, netting his side's both goals in a 2–0 win at [[Maccabi Herzliya F.C.|Maccabi Herzliya]].{{cite web|url=http://eng.football.org.il/Leagues/Pages/LeagueGameDetails.aspx?GAME_ID=113671|title=Maccabi Herzliya 0–2 Maccabi Haifa|publisher=Israel Football Association|date=26 May 2007|accessdate=30 June 2014}} In 2007, he travelled with the Under-21 side to [[2007 Torneo di Viareggio|that year]]'s [[Torneo di Viareggio]]; he scored once as Haifa was knocked-out in the group stage. Hemed was subsequently loaned to Maccabi Herzliya,{{cite web|url=http://www.one.co.il/Article/07-08/1,1,14,0/109497.html|script-title=he:תומר חמד יושאל למכבי הרצליה|trans-title=Tomer Hemed loaned to Maccabi Herzliya|language=Hebrew|publisher=One|date=30 January 2008|accessdate=30 June 2014}} [[Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv F.C.|Bnei Yehuda Tel Aviv]]{{cite web|url=http://www.one.co.il/Article/120140.html|script-title=he:תומר חמד הושאל ממכבי חיפה לבני יהודה|trans-title=Tomer Hemed of Maccabi Haifa loaned to Yehuda|language=Hebrew|publisher=One|date=20 July 2008|accessdate=30 June 2014}} and [[Maccabi Ahi Nazareth F.C.|Maccabi Ahi Nazareth]]{{cite web|url=http://www.one.co.il/Article/08-09/3,14,56,0/139830.html|script-title=he:מכבי אחי נצרת הולכת על שוער נבחרת חוף השנהב|trans-title=Maccabi Ahi Nazareth goes after Ivory Coast goalkeeper|language=Hebrew|publisher=One|date=1 July 2009|accessdate=30 June 2014}} (the latter being managed by [[John Gregory (footballer)|John Gregory]]).{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} Nazareth, however, finished last as Hemed scored nine goals.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} Hemed returned to Maccabi Haifa in the 2010 summer, and appeared in 45 matches during the [[2010–11 Israeli Premier League|2010–11 campaign]], also scoring 18 goals as the club was crowned champions.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} ===Mallorca=== On 21 June 2011, Hemed signed a three-year deal with Spanish [[La Liga]] club [[RCD Mallorca]].{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/06/21/futbol/equipos/mallorca/1308675238.html|title=El israelí Hemed, primer fichaje del Mallorca|trans-title=Israeli Hemed, first signing of Mallorca|language=Spanish|publisher=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|date=21 June 2011|accessdate=1 July 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/2011/06/23/futbol/equipos/mallorca/1308843873.html|title=Tomer Hemed: "Venir fue un dictamen de mi corazón"|trans-title=Tomer Hemed: "Coming was an opinion from my heart"|language=Spanish|publisher=Marca|date=23 June 2011|accessdate=1 July 2014}} He made his debut in the [[Spanish football league system|main category of the Spanish football]] on 28 August, starting and being [[Penalty card|booked]] in a 1–0 home success against [[RCD Espanyol]].{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/primera/jornada_2/mal_esp/|title=De Guzmán vale... tres puntos|trans-title=De Guzmán worths... three points|language=Spanish|publisher=Marca|date=28 August 2011|accessdate=1 July 2014}} Hemed scored his first goals abroad on 1 October, scoring both his side's goals in a 2–2 draw at [[CA Osasuna]].{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/primera/jornada_7/osa_mal/|title=Empate capicúa en Pamplona|trans-title=Palindrome draw in Pamplona|language=Spanish|publisher=Marca|date=1 October 2011|accessdate=1 July 2014}} He also netted twice in his [[Copa del Rey]] debut, a 6–1 home routing over [[Real Sociedad]] on 10 January of the following year.{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/copa/octavos/vuelta/mal_rso/|title=Un milagro en siete minutos|trans-title=A miracle in seven minutes|language=Spanish|publisher=Marca|date=10 January 2012|accessdate=1 July 2014}} Hemed finished [[2011–12 La Liga|his first season abroad]] with nine goals, although four of them were from the [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty spot]]. In [[2012–13 La Liga|his second season]] he scored 11 goals, with the [[Balearic Islands]] outfit being relegated, however. In May 2013 Hemed suffered an [[Achilles tendon rupture]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rcdmallorca.es/principal_new.php?nombreModulo=noticiasDetalle&idnoticia=32671&idseccion=2&idmenu=3&idsubmenu=21 |title=Parte médico Tomer Hemed |trans-title=Medical report Tomer Hemed |language=Spanish |publisher=Mallorca's official website |date=27 May 2013 |accessdate=1 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714143709/http://www.rcdmallorca.es/principal_new.php?nombreModulo=noticiasDetalle&idnoticia=32671&idseccion=2&idmenu=3&idsubmenu=21 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }} which kept him sidelined for seven months.{{cite web|url=http://www.rcdmallorca.es/principal_new.php?nombreModulo=noticiasDetalle&idmenu=3&idnoticia=33293 |title=Hemed: "Fue especial volver después de siete meses" |trans-title=Hemed: "It was special to return after seven months" |language=Spanish |publisher=Mallorca's official website |date=16 December 2013 |accessdate=1 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714131438/http://www.rcdmallorca.es/principal_new.php?nombreModulo=noticiasDetalle&idmenu=3&idnoticia=33293 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }} ===Almería=== On 2 July 2014 Hemed returned to the Spanish top level, by agreeing to a two-year deal with [[UD Almería]].{{cite web|url=http://www.udalmeriasad.com/-/el-almeria-ficha-a-tommer-hemed-un-delantero-de-garantias-para-el-nuevo-reto-en-primera |title=El Almería ficha a Tommer Hemed, un delantero de garantías para el nuevo reto en Primera |trans-title=Almería signs Tommer Hemed, a forward of assurances for the new challenge in ''Primera'' |language=Spanish |publisher=Almería's official website |date=2 July 2014 |accessdate=2 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707030528/http://www.udalmeriasad.com/-/el-almeria-ficha-a-tommer-hemed-un-delantero-de-garantias-para-el-nuevo-reto-en-primera |archivedate= 7 July 2014 |df= }} After struggling to score in his first matches, he netted his first goal with the [[Andalusia]]ns on 4 October, the last in a 2–2 home draw against [[Elche CF]]. In January 2015, Hemed scored two braces against [[Málaga CF]] (2–1 away win) and [[Valencia CF]] (2–3 away loss), taking his tally up to six. He finished [[2014–15 La Liga|the campaign]] with eight goals, being the club's top goalscorer, but suffered team relegation. ===Brighton & Hove Albion=== On 24 June 2015 Hemed signed a three-year deal with English [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] for an undisclosed fee. He scored his first goal for the Seagulls from the penalty spot in the last moments of an away game at Fulham, to seal a 2–1 victory.{{cite news|title=Fulham 1–2 Brighton: Late Hemed penalty seals points for Brighton|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11688/9951468/fulham-brighton|accessdate=15 April 2016|work=Sky Sports|date=15 August 2015}} Hemed scored just one goal between September 2015 and February 2016, which drew criticism from supporters, but rediscovered his early season form to finish as the club's top scorer with 17 goals. Hemed scored 13 goals in all competitions in Brighton's promotion-winning [[2016–17 EFL Championship|2016–17 season]], trading starting positions regularly with top-scorer [[Glenn Murray]] and [[Sam Baldock]] in a strike force that managed to score 44 league goals between them. Highlights from Hemed throughout the season included a last gasp equaliser in a 3–3 draw away to [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38786510|title=Brentford 3–3 Brighton & Hove Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 February 2017}} the only goal in a hard earned 1–0 win against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38786510|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1–0 Cardiff City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 January 2017}} and a late penalty in a narrow 1–0 away win against [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37324950|title=Burton Albion 0–1 Brighton & Hove Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 September 2016}} On 9 September 2017, Hemed scored his first [[Premier League]] goal for Brighton in a 3–1 victory over [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41133349|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 3–1 West Bromwich Albion|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=10 September 2017|date=9 September 2017}} Hemed scored again in Brighton's next home Premier League game, a 1–0 win against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 24 September.{{Cite news|url=http://m.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41297234|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1–0 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 September 2017}} Three days later, the [[The Football Association|FA]] announced that Hemed had been given a three-match ban for a stamp on the calf of Newcastle defender [[DeAndre Yedlin]], an incident which went unnoticed by referee [[Andre Marriner]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41419869 |title=Tomer Hemed: Brighton striker given three-match ban over DeAndre Yedlin incident |work=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2017}} On 16 November 2017, Hemed signed a contract extension with Brighton, keeping him on the south coast until the summer of 2019.{{Cite news|url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2017/november/hemed-signs-new-deal/|title=Hemed Signs New Deal|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion Football Club|date=16 November 2017}} ===Queens Park Rangers=== On 23 August 2018, Hemed joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web|url=https://www.qpr.co.uk/news/club-news/qpr-complete-tomer-hemed-loan-signing/|title=QPR complete Tomer Hemed loan signing|website=English}} Two days later he scored his first goal for the club on his debut against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in a 1–0 win at [[Loftus Road]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45229937|title=Queens Park Rangers 1–0 Wigan Athletic: Steve McClaren says R's 'will get better' after first win|date=25 August 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ==International career== Hemed appeared with the [[Israel national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[Israel national under-18 football team|under-18]], [[Israel national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Israel national under-21 football team|under-21]]s, featuring regularly with the youth squads. In January 2011, he was called up to the [[Israel national football team|main squad]] for a behind closed doors friendly against [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]]. Hemed made his unofficial debut on the 26th, scoring in a 3–2 win.{{cite web |url=http://video.fcdynamo.kiev.ua/match/friend_games/dynamo_izrael_26012011 |title=Dynamo Kyiv 2–3 Israel |language=Ukrainian|publisher=Dynamo Kiev Official Website|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=14 February 2011}} In May 2011, Hemed was called up to train with the national team for a friendly against [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] in June.{{cite web |url=http://football.org.il/Archive/Articles/Pages/nationalteam_11may2011.aspx |title=National Team for June |publisher=The Israel Football Association |accessdate=11 May 2011}} On 4 June, he made his international debut, starting and assisting [[Yossi Benayoun]] in a 2–1 victory.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Sports/Israel-takes-care-of-business-beats-Latvia-2-1|title=Israel takes care of business, beats Latvia 2–1|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|date=5 June 2011|accessdate=1 July 2014}} Hemed scored his first international goal on 6 September, but in a 1–3 loss against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2012/matches/round=15171/match=2002248/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Eduardo double against Israel sends Croatia top|publisher=[[UEFA]].com|date=6 September 2011|accessdate=1 July 2014}} He also scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 6–0 routing against [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]] on 12 October of the following year.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/worldcup/season=2014/matches/round=2000294/match=2008675/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Hemed hat-trick helps Israel overwhelm Luxembourg|publisher=UEFA.com|date=12 October 2012|accessdate=1 July 2014}} ===International goals=== :''As of match played 14 October 2018. Israel score listed first, score column indicates score after each Hemed goal.''{{cite web |url=http://eu-football.info/_player.php?id=27375 |title=Tomer Hemed |website=European Football Stadium]], [[Be'er Sheva]], Israel||align=center|34||{{fb|Albania}}||align=center|1–0||align=center|2–1||[[2018–19 UEFA Nations League C]]|| |} ==Personal life== Hemed is [[Jewish]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/21/beram-kayal-tomer-hemed-israelis-brighton|title=Beram Kayal and Tomer Hemed: Israelis united in promoting Brighton’s cause|first=Jacob|last=Steinberg|date=21 November 2015|website=the Guardian}} His father was born in [[Israel]] and is of Syrian-Jewish descent, whereas his mother was born in [[Poland]] to a Jewish family.{{Cite web|url=http://sportsrabbi.com/friday-feature-tomer-hemed-israeli-star/|title=Friday Feature – Tomer Hemed, Israeli Star {{!}} Sports Rabbi|website=sportsrabbi.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-17}} As a result, Hemed holds a Polish passport, which eased his move to European leagues.{{Cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/252404/Tomer-Hemed-s-passport-to-Rangers|title=Tomer Hemed's passport to Rangers|last=Macfarlane|first=Iain|date=2011-06-12|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=2018-07-17|language=en}} Hemed has described his ethnicity as "half [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazi]] and half [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardic]]." He is the youngest of four brothers. In 2013, he married Israeli model Shunit Faragi, where she was the Miss Israel contestant for [[Miss Universe 2008]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4395007,00.html|title=שונית פרג'י ותומר חמד התחתנו|first=שי|last=ארזואן|date=20 June 2013|publisher=|via=Ynet}} In 2014, they had their first daughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15669118.Hard_work_pays_off_for_Hemed_with_new_Albion_deal/|title=Hard work pays off for Hemed with new Albion deal|website=The Argus}} ==Career statistics== {{Infobox football biography | name = Percy Tau | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Percy Tau | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1994|5|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Witbank]], [[Mpumalanga]], [[South Africa]] | height = {{height|m=1.75}} | currentclub = [[Royale Union Saint-Gilloise|Union SG]]
(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C|Brighton]]) | clubnumber = 19 | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | years1 = 2013–2018 | clubs1 = [[Mamelodi Sundowns F.C.|Mamelodi Sundowns]] | caps1 = 65 | goals1 = 18 | years2 = 2015–2016 | clubs2 = → [[Witbank Spurs F.C.|Witbank Spurs]] (loan) | caps2 = 11 | goals2 = 3 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[Royale Union Saint-Gilloise|Union SG]] (loan) | caps4 = 21 | goals4 = 6 | nationalyears1 = 2015– | nationalteam1 = [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] | nationalcaps1 = 17 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | club-update = 9 October 2018 | ntupdate = 20 November 2018 }} '''Percy Tau''' (born 13 May 1994) is a South African professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Royale Union Saint-Gilloise|Union SG]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], and the [[South Africa national football team|South African national team]]. Tau began his footballing career with [[Premier Soccer League]] side [[Mamelodi Sundowns F.C.|Mamelodi Sundowns]] where he made 100 appearances either side of a loan to [[Witbank Spurs F.C.|Witbank Spurs]]. During his time with Sundowns, Tau won the league title twice and the [[CAF Champions League]] once and was named [[PSL Awards#Footballer of the Year|Footballer of the Year]] and joint-[[Lesley Manyathela Golden Boot|top-goalscorer]] in his final season with the ==Education== Percy Tau has earned a [BCom] at University of South Africa ==Club career== ===Mamelodi Sundowns=== Born in South Africa, Tau began his career with [[Mamelodi Sundowns F.C.|Mamelodi Sundowns]] in the [[Premier Soccer League]]. He made his professional debut for the club on 25 February 2014 in the league against [[Orlando Pirates]]. He came on as an 85th-minute substitute for [[Domingues]] as Sundowns lost 1–0.{{cite web|title=Sundowns 0–1 Orlando Pirates|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/02/25/south-africa/psl/mamelodi-sundowns/orlando-pirates/1528923/|website=Soccerway}} Tau then scored his first professional goal for the club during a [[Nedbank Cup]] match on 22 March 2014 against [[Lamontville Golden Arrows F.C.|Golden Arrows]]. His 90th-minute goal was the fourth and final goal for Sundowns as they won 4–1 against the Arrows.{{cite web|title=Golden Arrows 1–4 Sundowns|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/03/22/south-africa/cup/golden-arrows/mamelodi-sundowns/1654849/|website=Soccerway}} He then scored his first goal in international club competition on 5 April 2015 in a [[CAF Champions League]] match against [[TP Mazembe]]. He scored the Sundown's one and only goal of the match in the 84th minute as Mamelodi Sundowns fell 3–1.{{cite web|title=TP Mazembe 3–1 Sundowns|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/04/05/africa/caf-champions-league/tp-mazembe-englebert/mamelodi-sundowns/2014096/|website=Soccerway}} After two seasons and rarely appearing for Mamelodi Sundowns, Tau was placed on the club's release list for the 2014–15 season. On the advice of then-youth coach Rhulani Mokwena, he was [[Loan (sports)|loaned]] to [[National First Division]] side [[Witbank Spurs F.C.|Witbank Spurs]] instead.{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/sport/soccer/psl/how-percy-tau-went-from-slacker-to-superstar-at-mamelodi-sundowns-14785377|title=How Percy Tau went from slacker to superstar at Mamelodi Sundowns|publisher=Independent Online|last=Molefe|first=Mazola|date=4 May 2018|accessdate=30 July 2018}} He made his debut for the club on 6 February 2016 in a 3–1 win over [[African Warriors F.C.|African Warriors]] and went on to score 3 goals in 11 appearances during his loan spell.{{cite web|title=African Warriors 1–3 Witbank Spurs|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/02/06/south-africa/1st-division/african-warriors/witbank-spurs/2126739/|website=Soccerway}} After a season with Witbank Spurs, Tau rejoined Mamelodi Sundowns and was included in the squad for the club's [[CAF Champions League]] campaign. He featured throughout and played every minute of both legs of a 3–1 aggregate win over Egyptian side [[Zamalek SC|Zamalek]] in the [[2017 CAF Champions League#Final|CAF Champions League Final]]. The victory was Sundowns' first ever triumph in a continental competition.{{cite web|title=Zamalek 1–0 Sundowns|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/10/23/africa/caf-champions-league/zamalek/mamelodi-sundowns/2360486/|website=Soccerway}} He then scored his first goal in the league for the club on 2 November 2016 against [[Polokwane City F.C.|Polokwane City]]. He scored the first of two goals for the side as they went on to win 2–0.{{cite web|title=Polokwane City 0–2 Sundowns|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/11/02/south-africa/psl/bay-united/mamelodi-sundowns/2325311/|website=Soccerway}} Tau then made his debut for the side in the [[FIFA Club World Cup]] on 11 December 2016 against [[Kashima Antlers]]. Sundowns were knocked-out of the competition after losing to the Japanese side 2–0.{{cite web|title=Sundowns 0–2 Kashima Antlers|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/12/11/world/fifa-club-world-cup/mamelodi-sundowns/kashima-antlers/2359991/|website=Soccerway}} During the fifth place match, Tau scored the only goal for Sundowns as they fell 4–1 to [[Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors FC|Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors]] of South Korea.{{cite web|title=Jeonbuk Motors 4–1 Sundowns|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/12/14/world/fifa-club-world-cup/chonbuk/mamelodi-sundowns/2357629/|website=Soccerway}} During the 2017–18 season, Tau scored 11 goals to help Mamelodi Sundowns to the league title. His form throughout the season saw him share the [[Lesley Manyathela Golden Boot]] with [[Rodney Ramagalela]] and earned him the Footballer of the Season and Players' Player of the Season awards.{{cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/soccer/2018-05-29-sundowns-percy-tau-walks-away-with-top-honours-at-glittering-psl-awards/|title=Sundowns' Percy Tau walks away with top honours at glittering PSL awards|publisher=Times Live|last=Ntloko|first=Mninwa|date=29 May 2018|accessdate=29 May 2018}} As a result of his achievements, Tau was courted by a number of European clubs during the off-season. Amidst the speculation surrounding his future, he refused to join Sundowns in the pre-season preparations in an attempt to force through a move.{{cite news|url=https://fansided.com/2018/07/23/percy-tau-star-waiting-brighton/|title=Percy Tau is a star in waiting for Brighton|publisher=FanSided|last=Bekker|first=Liam|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=30 July 2018}}{{cite news|url= https://www.sowetanlive.co.za/sport/soccer/2018-07-24-percy-taus-agent-thrilled-move-finally-happened/|title=Percy Tau's agent thrilled move finally happened|publisher=Sowetan Live|last=Motshwane|first=Gomolemo|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=30 July 2018}} ===Brighton & Hove Albion=== On 20 July 2018, Tau signed a four-year contract with [[English football|English]] [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]],{{cite web|url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2018/july/albion-complete-striker-signing/|title=Albion complete striker signing|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|accessdate=20 July 2018}} for an undisclosed transfer fee, reported to be in the region of [[South African Rand|R]]50 million ([[Pound sterling|UK£]]2.7 million), a South African record sale of a domestic player. Brighton manager, [[Chris Hughton]], confirmed that Tau would be loaned out shortly after his transfer, after failing a [[UK work permit]], as well as him wanting the South African international to gain European football experience.{{cite web|url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2018/july/tau-excited-to-make-loan-impact/|title=Tau excited to make loan impact|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|accessdate=20 July 2018}} On 15 August, Tau joined [[Belgian First Division B|Belgian second division]] side [[Royale Union Saint-Gilloise|Union SG]], owned by Brighton chairman [[Tony Bloom]],https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/16239606.done-deal-albion-chairman-tony-bloom-completes-takeover-of-belgian-club-saint-gilloise/ on a season-long loan.{{cite news|url=https://www.sport24.co.za/Soccer/PSL/breaking-percy-tau-joins-belgian-second-division-side-20180815|title=BREAKING: Percy Tau joins Belgian second division side|publisher=News 24|date=15 August 2018|accessdate=15 August 2018}} ==International career== Tau made his debut for [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] on 17 October 2015 in a 0–2 loss to [[Angola national football team|Angola]] in a [[2016 African Nations Championship qualification]] match. On Saturday, 25 March 2017, Tau scored his first international goal in the 69th minute against [[Guinea-Bissau national football team|Guinea-Bissau]] after receiving a yellow card two minutes earlier. ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|30 July 2018}}{{soccerway|331332}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !colspan="3"|League !colspan="2"|Cup1 !colspan="2"|League Cup2 !colspan="2"|Continental3 !colspan="2"|Other4 !colspan="2"|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan="5"|[[Mamelodi Sundowns F.C.|Mamelodi Sundowns]] |[[2013–14 South African Premier Division|2013–14]] |rowspan=4|[[South African Premier Division]]||1||0||1||1||0||0||—||—||0||0||2||1 |- |[[2014–15 South African Premier Division|2014–15]] |5||0||1||0||0||0||1||1||1||0||8||1 |- |[[2016–17 South African Premier Division|2016–17]] |29||7||1||0||2||0||7||2||4||0||43||11 |- |[[2017–18 South African Premier Division|2017–18]] |30||11||3||2||1||0||10||0||3||1||47||14 |- !colspan="2"|Total !65!!18!!6!!3!!3!!0!!18!!3!!8!!1!!100!!25 |- |rowspan="1"|[[Witbank Spurs F.C.|Witbank Spurs]] (loan) |[[2015–16 National First Division|2015–16]] |[[National First Division]]||11||3||0||0||—||—||—||—||–||–||11||3 |- !colspan="3"|Career total !76!!21!!6!!3!!3!!0!!18!!3!!8!!1!!111!!28 |} 1 Includes [[Nedbank Cup]] matches.

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Markus Suttner | image = AUT vs. MDA 2015-09-05 (094).jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Suttner with [[Austria national football team|Austria]] in 2015 | fullname = Markus Suttner{{cite web |title=Squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/465277 |publisher=Premier League |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=9 September 2017}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1987|4|16}} | birth_place = [[Hollabrunn]], Austria | height = {{height|m=1.79|precision=0}} | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Full-back]] | currentclub = [[Fortuna Düsseldorf]]
(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]) | clubnumber = 14 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Austria Wien]] | years1 = 2007–2015 | clubs1 = [[FK Austria Wien|Austria Wien]] | caps1 = 207 | goals1 = 9 | years2 = 2015–2017 | clubs2 = [[FC Ingolstadt 04]] | caps2 = 49 | goals2 = 4 | years3 = 2017– | clubs3 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps3 = 14 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2019– | clubs4 = → [[Fortuna Düsseldorf]] (loan) | caps4 = 0 | goals4 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[Austria national under-21 football team|Austria U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 7 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2012–2017 | nationalteam2 = [[Austria national football team|Austria]] | nationalcaps2 = 20 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 14:29, 19 January 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 14 July 2017 }} '''Markus Suttner''' (born 16 April 1987) is an Austrian professional footballer who plays as a defender for [[Bundesliga]] club [[Fortuna Düsseldorf]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. Suttner came through the youth system at [[Austria Wien]], where he went on to play over 200 games before moving to [[FC Ingolstadt 04]]. On 18 January 2019, after no appearances for Brighton & Hove Albion during the 2018-19 season, he joined Fortuna Düsseldorf on loan until the end of the season.https://rp-online.de/sport/fussball/fortuna/fortuna-duesseldorf-holt-markus-suttner-von-brighton-und-hove-albion_aid-35718933https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11741/11610336/brightons-markus-suttner-to-join-fortuna-dusseldorf-on-loan Suttner made seven appearances for [[Austria national football team|Austria's]] Under-21 side, before making his full debut on 1 June 2012, in the 3–2 win over [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] in a [[friendly match]]. After 20 caps, it was announced on 10 May 2017, that he had retired from international football.https://twitter.com/oefb1904/status/862214514988732417 - ÖFB Twitter post (German) ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|end of 2017–18 season}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|National Cup !colspan=2|League Cup !colspan=2|Continental !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=8|[[FK Austria Wien]]{{cite web |url=https://www.worldfootball.net/player_summary/markus-suttner/2/ |title=Markus Suttner: Club matches |website=WorldFootball.net |publisher=Heim:Spiel |accessdate=8 June 2018}} |[[2008–09 FK Austria Wien season|2008–09]] |rowspan=7|[[Austrian Football Bundesliga|Austrian
Bundesliga]] |22||0||2||0||colspan=2|—||0||0||24||0 |- |[[2009–10 FK Austria Wien season|2009–10]] |27||0||3||0||colspan=2|—||5{{efn|name=UEL|Appearances in [[UEFA Europa League]]}}||0||35||0 |- |[[2010–11 FK Austria Wien season|2010–11]] |27||2||1||0||colspan=2|—||6{{efn|name=UEL}}||0||34||2 |- |[[2011–12 FK Austria Wien season|2011–12]] |30||1||3||0||colspan=2|—||12{{efn|name=UEL}}||0||45||1 |- |[[2012–13 FK Austria Wien season|2012–13]] |35||3||5||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||40||3 |- |[[2013-14 FK Austria Wien season|2013–14]] |35||2||2||0||colspan=2|—||9{{efn|Appearances in [[UEFA Champions League]]}}||0||46||2 |- |[[2014-15 FK Austria Wien season|2014–15]] |31||1||5||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||36||1 |- !colspan=2|Total !207||9||21||0||colspan=2|—||32||0||260||9 |- |rowspan=3|[[FC Ingolstadt 04]]{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/markus-suttner/35785/ |title=M. Suttner |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=8 June 2018}} |[[2015–16 FC Ingolstadt 04 season|2015–16]] |rowspan=2|[[Bundesliga]] |18||0||1||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||19||0 |- |[[2016–17 FC Ingolstadt 04 season|2016–17]] |31||4||2||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||33||4 |- !colspan=2|Total !49||4||3||0||colspan=2|—||0||0|||52||4 |- |[[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] |[[2017–18 Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|57817|2017|accessdate=8 June 2018}} |[[Premier League]] |14||0||3||0||0||0||colspan=2|—||17||0 |- !colspan=3|Career totals !270||13||27||0||0||0||32||0||329||13 |} {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Soccerbase}} * [http://eu-football.info/_player.php?id=27647 Player's profile], eu-football.info * {{NFT|35930}} {{Austria squad UEFA Euro 2016}} {{Fortuna Düsseldorf squad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Suttner, Markus}} [[Category:Austrian footballers]] [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Austria under-21 international footballers]] [[Category:Austria youth international footballers]] [[Category:Austria international footballers]] [[Category:Austrian expatriate footballers]] [[Category:Association football defenders]] [[Category:Austrian Football Bundesliga players]] [[Category:FK Austria Wien players]] [[Category:Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. players]] [[Category:FC Ingolstadt 04 players]] [[Category:Bundesliga players]] [[Category:Premier League players]] [[Category:Expatriate footballers in Germany]] [[Category:Expatriate footballers in England]] [[Category:UEFA Euro 2016 players]] {{austria-footy-defender-stub}}

{{Use British English|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Christian Walton | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Christian Timothy Walton{{Hugman|26896|accessdate=25 June 2016}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1995|11|9|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Wadebridge]], England | height = {{convert|1.96|m|order=flip}}{{cite web |title=C. Walton |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/christian-walton/217741/ |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=18 February 2018}} | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]]
(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]) | clubnumber = 1 | youthyears1 = 2005–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] | youthyears2 = 2013 | youthclubs2 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | years1 = 2013– | clubs1 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps1 = 3 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2015 | clubs2 = → [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] (loan) | caps2 = 4 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2015–2016 | clubs3 = → [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] (loan) | caps3 = 4 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2016–2017 | clubs4 = → [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] (loan) | caps4 = 27 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2017 | clubs5 = → [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] (loan) | caps5 = 7 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2017–2018 | clubs6 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | caps6 = 31 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2018– | clubs7 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | caps7 = 27 | goals7 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2014 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2016 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 1 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 17:02, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Christian Timothy Walton''' (born 9 November 1995) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for {{English football updater|WiganAth}} club [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|Brigh&HA}} club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. He has represented England at [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]], [[England national under-20 football team|under-20]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels. ==Club career== ===Plymouth Argyle=== Born in [[Wadebridge]], Cornwall, Walton began his career with [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] aged 10 and progressed through the club's [[youth system]]. He was named in a matchday squad for the first time three days after his 16th birthday for an [[FA Cup]] first round tie against [[Stourbridge F.C.|Stourbridge]], in which he remained an unused [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]], the match finishing 3–3.{{cite web |title=Plymouth 3–3 Stourbridge |url=http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10364~61283,00.html |publisher=Plymouth Argyle F.C. |date=12 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114140910/http://www.pafc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10364~61283%2C00.html |archivedate=14 November 2011 |deadurl=yes}} ===Brighton & Hove Albion and loan spells=== On 15 February 2013, Walton signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], where he completed his scholarship, before signing a three-year professional contract in the summer of 2013.{{cite web |first=Will |last=Jago |title=Albion sign Christian Walton |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2013/february/albion-sign-christian-walton/ |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=15 February 2013 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} He was twice an unused substitute in consecutive matches in [[2013–14 Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. season|2013–14]], a 3–1 win at home to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on 7 December,{{cite news |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 3–1 Leicester City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25163803 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 December 2013 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} prior to a 1–0 win away to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] one week later.{{cite news |title=Middlesbrough 0–1 Brighton & Hove Albion |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25275222 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} Ahead of [[2014–15 Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. season|2014–15]], Walton signed a new four-year contract with the club on 8 July 2014.{{cite news |title=Brighton: Jake Forster-Caskey and Christian Walton sign new deals |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28216271 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 July 2014 |accessdate=29 October 2014}} He was an unused substitute on the opening day of the season in a 1–0 defeat at home to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].{{cite news |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 0–1 Sheffield Wednesday |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28646509 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} Walton made his professional debut for Brighton aged 18 in a 2–0 defeat away to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] fourth round on 29 October.{{cite news |first=David |last=Hytner |title=Tottenham cruise into last eight as Érik Lamela and Harry Kane sink Brighton |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/oct/29/tottenham-brighton-capital-one-cup-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=29 October 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} He made his [[English Football League|Football League]] debut six days later in a 1–0 win at home to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].{{cite news |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1–0 Wigan Athletic |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29797381 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 November 2014 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} Walton made his second consecutive start in a 1–1 draw at home to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 8 November.{{cite news |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1–1 Blackburn Rovers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29860092 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 November 2014 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} He returned to the [[starting lineup]] on the final day of the season in a 0–0 draw away to Middlesbrough, his first appearance since November.{{cite web |title=Report: Middlesbrough 0 Albion 0 |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2015/may/middlesbrough-v-albion-/ |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=2 May 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} In addition to his four appearances for Brighton, Walton also kept two [[clean sheets]]. On 21 July 2015, Walton signed for newly promoted [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]].{{cite news |title=Christian Walton: Bury sign Brighton & Hove Albion keeper |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33608899 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 July 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}} He made his debut for Bury in a 1–1 draw at home to [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] on the opening day of [[2015–16 Bury F.C. season|2015–16]].{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Brown |title=Match report: Bury 1–1 Doncaster Rovers |url=https://www.buryfc.co.uk/news/2015/august/match-report-bury-1---1-doncaster-rovers/ |publisher=Bury F.C. |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} Walton returned to Brighton on 1 September due to an underlying groin injury, having made six appearances for Bury.{{cite web |first=Paul |last=Camillin |title=Walton returns |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2015/september/walton-returns/ |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=1 September 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} On 19 November 2015, Walton joined former club Plymouth Argyle on loan until 3 January 2016 as cover for the injured [[Luke McCormick]].{{cite web |first=Paul |last=Camillin |title=Walton joins Argyle on loan |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2015/november/walton-joins-argyle-on-loan/ |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=19 November 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} He made his Plymouth debut in a 2–1 defeat at home to arch-rivals [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] two days later.{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Errington |title=Plymouth Argyle 1 Exeter City 2: Match report |url=http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/Plymouth-Argyle-1-Exeter-City-2-Match-report/story-28218039-detail/story.html |newspaper=Plymouth Herald |date=21 November 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125125800/http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/Plymouth-Argyle-1-Exeter-City-2-Match-report/story-28218039-detail/story.html |archivedate=25 November 2015 |deadurl=yes}} Walton started in three further matches, and returned to Brighton upon the expiration of his loan spell.{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Errington |title=Goalkeeper Christian Walton returns to Brighton after Plymouth Argyle loan ends |url=http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/goalkeeper-christian-walton-returns-brighton/story-28457304-detail/story.html |newspaper=Plymouth Herald |date=3 January 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016}}{{dead link|date=February 2018}} On 24 June 2016, Walton signed for [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] on a season-long loan, linking back up with [[Nathan Jones (Welsh footballer)|Nathan Jones]] who was [[first-team]] coach for his first three years at Brighton.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Simmonds |title=Hatters sign Seagulls keeper on season-long loan |url=https://www.lutontoday.co.uk/sport/football/luton-town/hatters-sign-seagulls-keeper-on-season-long-loan-1-7448076 |newspaper=Luton Today |date=24 June 2016 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} He made his Luton debut on the opening day of [[2016–17 Luton Town F.C. season|2016–17]] in a 3–0 win away to Plymouth Argyle.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Simmonds |title=Hatters head to the top after superb Plymouth win |url=https://www.lutontoday.co.uk/sport/football/luton-town/hatters-head-to-the-top-after-superb-plymouth-win-1-7515160 |newspaper=Luton Today |date=6 August 2016 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} Walton saved a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] from [[Vadaine Oliver]] during a 0–0 draw away to [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] on 29 October to keep a clean sheet for Luton, which extended the club's unbeaten league run to seven matches and earned him a place in the English Football League Team of the Week.{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Butcher |title=Sky Bet EFL: Team of the Week |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2016/october/sky-bet-efl-team-of-the-week5/ |publisher=English Football League |date=31 October 2016 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} He was recalled by Brighton on 31 January 2017 following an injury to fellow goalkeeper [[Niki Mäenpää]], having made 33 appearances for Luton and conceded the fewest goals in League Two during his loan spell.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Simmonds |title=Deadline day: Brighton recall keeper Walton from Luton |url=https://www.lutontoday.co.uk/sport/football/luton-town/deadline-day-brighton-recall-keeper-walton-from-luton-1-7799344 |newspaper=Luton Today |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} On 1 April 2017, Walton signed for League One club [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] on an emergency loan for an initial seven days as cover for [[Ted Smith (footballer, born 1996)|Ted Smith]] who had sustained a wrist injury.{{cite news |title=Christian Walton: Brighton goalkeeper joins Southend as emergency cover |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39466810 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 April 2017 |accessdate=1 April 2017}}{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Phillips |title=Blues snap up goalkeeper Walton on loan from Brighton |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/blues/15197542.Blues_snap_up_goalkeeper_Walton_on_loan_from_Brighton/ |newspaper=The Echo |location=Basildon |date=1 April 2017 |accessdate=1 April 2017}} He debuted later that day in a 3–0 victory at home to [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]].{{cite news |title=Southend United 3–0 Oldham Athletic |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39389230 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 April 2017 |accessdate=1 April 2017}} It was agreed for Walton's loan to be extended by a further week as the club were still without a fit goalkeeper.{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Naylor |title=Brighton and Hove Albion goalkeeper Christian Walton staying at Southend United |url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15212491.Albion_goalie_kept_for_longer_by_Southend/ |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=8 April 2017 |accessdate=8 April 2017}} The goalkeeping situation remained unchanged and therefore the loan was extended by a further week once more.{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Owen |title=Christian Walton stays on loan at Southend United for another week |url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/15227632.Walton_stays_at_Southend_for_another_week/ |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=16 April 2017 |accessdate=17 April 2017}} Walton's loan was extended again to enable him to play in Southend's final match of [[2016–17 Southend United F.C. season|2016–17]],{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Owen |title=Christian Walton cleared to play for Southend United in play-off decider |url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/albion/15256078.Walton_clear_for_action_in_play_off_decider/ |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=30 April 2017 |accessdate=30 April 2017}} and completed the loan spell with seven appearances. On 12 July 2017, Walton signed for League One club Wigan Athletic on a season-long loan.{{cite news |title=Christian Walton: Wigan Athletic sign Brighton goalkeeper on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40582430 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 July 2017 |accessdate=13 July 2017}} He made his debut for Wigan on the opening day of [[2017–18 Wigan Athletic F.C. season|2017–18]] in a 1–0 victory away to [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]]. Walton finished the loan with 35 appearances, as Wigan won the League One title and [[Promotion and relegation|promotion]] to the Championship.{{cite web |title=League One: 2017/18: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=1568 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=5 May 2018}} He re-signed for Wigan on another season-long loan on 22 June 2018, with a recall option in January 2019.{{cite news |title=Christian Walton: Wigan Athletic re-sign Brighton goalkeeper on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44576851 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018}} ==International career== Walton was called up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19 team]] for a [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] against [[Turkey national under-19 football team|Turkey]] on 5 March 2014.{{cite web |first=Jamie |last=Reid |title=Noel Blake names England U19s squad for Turkey fixture |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2014/feb/24/blake-names-u19s-squad-for-turkey |publisher=The Football Association |date=24 February 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} He entered the match as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Mitchell Beeney]], the match finishing a 3–0 win.{{cite web |first=Jamie |last=Reid |title=England U19s shine in Chester as Young Lions beat Turkey |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2014/mar/05/england-v-turkey-match-report |publisher=The Football Association |date=5 March 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} Walton received his first call-up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] for a friendly against [[Romania national under-19 football team|Romania]],{{cite web |first=Jamie |last=Reid |title=Aidy Boothroyd names U20 squad to face Romania |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2014/aug/28/boothroyd-names-his-first-u20-squad |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 August 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} in which he won his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]].{{cite web |first=Jamie |last=Reid |title=Boothroyd's boys hit Romania for six in Telford |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2014/sep/05/england-v-romania-u20-match-report-050914 |publisher=The Football Association |date=5 September 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2017}} He was first called up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]] on 25 August 2015 for their matches against the [[United States men's national under-23 soccer team|United States under-23 team]] and [[Norway national under-21 football team|Norway under-21 team]].{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Collins |title=Duncan Watmore and Bury keeper Christian Walton named in England Under-21 squad |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/duncan-watmore-bury-keeper-christian-9925531 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=25 August 2015 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} However, he was forced to withdraw from the squad six days later after sustaining a groin injury playing for Bury in a 1–1 draw with Oldham Athletic.{{cite news |first=Craig |last=Nelson |title=Bury keeper Christian Walton is withdrawn from England U21 squad |url=http://www.burytimes.co.uk/sport/13636844.Bury_keeper_Christian_Walton_is_withdrawn_from_England_U21_squad/ |newspaper=Bury Times |date=31 August 2015 |accessdate=12 October 2016}} Walton received his next under-21 call-up on 3 October 2016 for two [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification]] matches against [[Kazakhstan national under-21 football team|Kazakhstan]] and [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national under-21 football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]].{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Simmonds |title=Luton keeper earns England U21 call-up |url=https://www.lutontoday.co.uk/sport/football/luton-town/luton-keeper-earns-england-u21-call-up-1-7609189 |newspaper=Luton Today |date=3 October 2016 |accessdate=18 February 2018}} He won his first cap and kept a [[clean sheet]] in England's 5–0 win over Bosnia and Herzegovina on 11 October.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Simmonds |title=Clean sheet for Luton keeper on England U21s debut |url=https://www.lutontoday.co.uk/sport/football/luton-town/clean-sheet-for-luton-keeper-on-england-u21s-debut-1-7624419 |newspaper=Luton Today |date=11 October 2016 {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Ben Barclay | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Benjamin Barclay{{cite web |title=EFL: Retained list: 2015/16 |url=http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf |publisher=English Football League |page=11 |format=PDF |accessdate=9 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202052144/http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf |archivedate=2 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|10|7|df=y}}{{cite web | title = Ben Barclay | url = https://www.11v11.com/players/ben-white-253530/ | website= 11v11.com | publisher = AFS Enterprises | accessdate =10 September 2017}} | birth_place = [[Altrincham]], England | height = | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre-back]] | currentclub = [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]]
(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]) | clubnumber = 6 | youthyears1 = 2004–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Manchester City]] | youthyears2 = 2013–2018 | youthclubs2 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion]] | years1 = 2018– | clubs1 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2019– | clubs2 = → [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] (loan) | caps2 = 10 | goals2 = 0 | club-update = 17:02, 9 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Benjamin Barclay''' (born 7 October 1996) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre-back]] for [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. ==Club Career== ===Brighton & Hove Albion=== Barclay played regularly for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. Reserves and Academy|Brighton U23's]] and made a number of appearances for the Sussex club in the [[Premier League 2]] league in the last few seasons. The former [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] youth player was included in [[Chris Hughton|Chris Hughton's]] 25 man squad for the [[2018-19 Premier League]] season.{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/teams/first-team/defender/ben-barclay/#|title=Ben Barclay - Defender - First Team - Brighton & Hove Albion|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion|date=|accessdate=}} He made his debut for Brighton on 28 August 2018, in the [[EFL Cup]] at home against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] where he played the full match in a 1-0 loss against their south coast rivals.https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/16603946 ====Loan to Notts County==== On 4 January 2019, Barclay joined [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2019/january/loan-switch-for-albion-defensive-pair/|title=LOAN SWITCH FOR ALBION DEFENSIVE PAIR|publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=4 January 2019 |accessdate=4 January 2019}} Barclay made his Notts County debut a day after joining the club in a [[2018-19 EFL League Two|League Two]] fixture away against Essex club [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] where it eventually finished 3-3 in what also happened to be his first ever league match.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46707291|title=Colchester United 3-3 Notts County - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport|date= 5 January 2019 |accessdate=5 January 2019}} ==Career statistics== {{Updated|match played 9 March 2019}} {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center;" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL Cup|League Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=1|[[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] |[[2018–19 Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. season|2018–19]] |[[Premier League]] |0||0||colspan=2|—||1||0||colspan=2|—||1||0 |- !colspan=3|Total !0!!0!!0!!0!!1!!0!!0!!0!!1!!0 |- |rowspan=1|[[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] (loan) |[[2018–19 Notts County F.C. season|2018–19]] |[[League Two]] |10||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||10||0 |- !colspan=3|Career Total !10!!0!!0!!0!!1!!0!!0!!0!!11!!0 |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Notts County F.C. squad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barclay, Ben}} [[Category:1996 births]] [[Category:English footballers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. players]] [[Category:Association football defenders]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Richie Towell | image = Richie Towell.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Towell playing for [[Dundalk F.C.|Dundalk]] in 2015 | fullname = Richard Patrick Towell{{cite web |url=http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf |title=EFL: Retained list: 2015/16 |publisher=English Football League |page=11 |format=PDF |accessdate=26 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202052144/http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf |archivedate=2 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|7|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Inchicore]], [[Dublin]], Ireland | height = | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]]
(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]) | clubnumber = 13 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Crumlin United F.C.|Crumlin United]] | youthyears2 = 2007–2010 | youthclubs2 = [[Celtic F.C. Reserve and Youth squads|Celtic]] | years1 = 2010–2012 | clubs1 = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] | caps1 = 1 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2011–2012 | clubs2 = → [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] (loan) | caps2 = 30 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2013–2015 | clubs3 = [[Dundalk F.C.|Dundalk]] | caps3 = 96 | goals3 = 43 | years4 = 2015– | clubs4 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps4 = 1 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2017–2018 | clubs5 = → [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] (loan) | caps5 = 39 | goals5 = 5 | years6 = 2018– | clubs6 = → [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] (loan) | caps6 = 27 | goals6 = 4 | nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-17 football team|Republic of Ireland U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam2 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-19 football team|Republic of Ireland U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 6 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2010–2012 | nationalteam3 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Republic of Ireland U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 9 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 16:58, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Richard Patrick Towell''' (born 17 July 1991) is an Irish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] (on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]). Towell started his career with Scottish club [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] and made his debut in the first half of the [[2010–11 Celtic F.C. season|2010–11 season]]. He then had two loan spells with [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] before leaving Celtic in 2012. Towell has represented the [[Republic of Ireland under-21 national football team|Republic of Ireland under-21]], [[Republic of Ireland national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Republic of Ireland national under-17 football team|under-17]] teams ==Club career== ===Celtic=== Towell started his career at [[Crumlin United F.C.|Crumlin United]] and in 2007 moved to Celtic. In November 2010, he made his professional debut coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Jos Hooiveld]] in the 57th minute of Celtic's 2–2 draw against [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness]],{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/9230565.stm |title=Celtic 2–2 Inverness CT |date=27 November 2010 |website= |publisher=BBC |accessdate=6 January 2011}} he provided an assist for [[Paddy McCourt]]. ====Hibernian (loans)==== On 25 January 2011, he joined [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] on loan until the end of the 2010–11 season.{{cite news|url=http://www.hibernianfc.co.uk/news/20110125/irish-defender-signs-on-loan_2262950_2276355 |title=Irish Defender Signs on Loan |publisher=Hibernian F.C. |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128225207/http://www.hibernianfc.co.uk/news/20110125/irish-defender-signs-on-loan_2262950_2276355 |archivedate=28 January 2011 }} Towell made his debut a day later, in a 2–0 loss to [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/9372935.stm|title=Hibs 0–2 Rangers|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}} He was at fault for the concession of the second Rangers goal, as a misplaced pass allowed [[Nikica Jelavić]] a clear chance to score. Despite this bad start, Towell helped to solidify the Hibs defence during the latter part of the 2010–11 season. Hibs manager [[Colin Calderwood]] stated in April 2011 that he hoped to sign Towell for a longer period.{{cite news|url=http://sport.scotsman.com/top-stories/Hibs-keen-to-tie-down.6753164.jp|publisher=Johnston Press|first=Iain|last=Collin|date=17 April 2011|accessdate=17 April 2011|work=[[Scotland on Sunday]]|title=Hibs keen to tie down on-loan Richie Towell on a more permanent contract}} Towell said in April 2011 that he received abuse from [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] supporters in [[Edinburgh derby]] matches because he was Catholic.{{cite news|url=http://sport.scotsman.com/sport/39I39ll-get-abuse-because-I39m.6744599.jp|title='I'll get abuse because I'm a Catholic,' says Towell|work=[[The Scotsman]]|publisher=Johnston Press|date=2 April 2011|accessdate=2 April 2011|last=Bathgate|first=Stuart}} However, he also said that this made him more determined to play better.{{cite news|url=http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/edinburgh/Edinburgh-derby-39Rivalry-is-a.6744737.jp|work=[[Edinburgh Evening News]]|publisher=Johnston Press|date=2 April 2011|accessdate=2 April 2011|title=Edinburgh derby: 'Rivalry is a million miles from Old Firm'}} Towell returned to Celtic at the end of the season, having made 15 starting appearances for Hibs. Towell re-signed on loan for Hibs on 25 August 2011, on a deal due to run until June 2012.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14669133.stm|title=Celtic's Richie Towell rejoins Hibernian|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=25 August 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011}} He played the first match of his second loan spell only 3 days later, starting as Hibs lost 2–0 to [[Edinburgh derby]] rivals Hearts.{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/scottish-premier/8728406/Hearts-2-Hibernian-0-match-report.html | title = Hearts 2 Hibernian 0: match report | publisher = |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 28 August 2011 | accessdate = 29 August 2011}} Towell started to find first-team opportunities limited after new manager [[Pat Fenlon]] made several siginings in the January transfer window. Two right backs and two central midfielders came in with one other right back going out. However, Fenlon said that once Towell had got his fitness levels up he would be back in the first team picture.{{cite news | url = http://www.scotsman.com/edinburgh-evening-news/sport/pat-fenlon-says-richie-towell-still-has-hibs-role-1-2103672 | title = Pat Fenlon says Richie Towell still has Hibs role | publisher = Johnston Press|work= The Scotsman | date = 8 February 2012 | accessdate = 19 March 2012}} ===Dundalk=== Towell was signed by [[Stephen Kenny (footballer)|Stephen Kenny]] for [[Dundalk F.C.|Dundalk]] in December 2012, ahead of the 2013 Airtricity Premier Division season.{{cite news|title=Dundalk confirm signing of Celtic's Richie Towell and re-signing of Stephen McDonnell|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/news/3942/ireland/2012/12/19/3613531/dundalk-confirm-signing-of-celtics-richie-towell-and-re#|publisher=Goal.com|date=19 December 2012|accessdate=29 December 2012}} Towell made his League of Ireland debut against Shamrock Rovers on the opening night of the 2013 season and was hugely influential in Dundalk’s second-placed finish that year, scoring seven times in 31 league appearances. He also picked up the [[PFAI]] Young Player of the Year award. He won back to back league titles with Dundalk in 2014 and 2015 scoring 11 and 25 goals in the respective seasons, and got his first taste of Champions League football with the [[League of Ireland]] champions. ===Brighton & Hove Albion=== Towell signed for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 30 November 2015. Towell made his debut for the Sussex club in the third round of the [[2015-16 FA Cup]] on 9 January 2016 away against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] where The Seagulls lost 1-0 to a [[Robert Snodgrass]] penalty. Despite not playing a single league game in the [[2015-16 Football League Championship]] season Towell made an appearance in the [[2016 Football League play-offs|2016 Championship play-offs]] as a substitute away against [[Sheffield Wednesday]] where Brighton were beaten 2-0 and 3-1 on aggregate.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/36165388 |title= Championship play-offs: Sheffield Wednesday 2-0 Brighton as it happened - Live - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport |date= 13 May 2016 |accessdate= 13 May 2016}} Towell scored his first goal for The Albion in a 3-1 [[FA Cup]] loss away to then [[National League]] side [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln]] on 28 January 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/richie-towell-brighton-injury-3063167-Nov2016/|title=Former Dundalk star Richie Towell edges towards Brighton comeback|first=Shane|last=Costello|publisher=}}{{cite news|title=Richie Towell departs Dundalk to sign for Championship high-flyers Brighton|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/league-of-ireland/richie-towell-departs-dundalk-to-sign-for-championship-highflyers-brighton-34245085.html|accessdate=30 November 2015|publisher=independent.ie|date=30 November 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38700730 |title= Lincoln City 3-1 Brighton & Hove Albion - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 January 2017 |accessdate=28 January 2017}} Towell's only league game to date with The Seagulls came against his then future loan club [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham]] on 7 March 2017 where he came on as a substitute where Brighton won 2-0 at the [[New York Stadium]]. At the end of the season Brighton & Hove Albion were promoted to the [[Premier League]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39111438 |title=Rotherham United 0-2 Brighton & Hove Albion - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 March 2017 |accessdate= 7 March 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/39422564 |title=Brighton promoted to Premier League - relive EFL action as it happened - Live - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 April 2017 |accessdate= 17 April 2017}} In May 2017, following Brighton's promotion to the [[Premier League]], Towell signed a deal to keep him at the club until 2019. ====Rotherham (loans)==== On 31 August 2017, he signed for [[EFL League One|League One]]'s Rotherham on a season-long loan where he helped them regain their Championship status, winning the [[2018 English Football League play-offs|2018 EFL League One play-offs]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.themillers.co.uk/news/2017/august/signing--millers-land-late-deal-for-towell/|title=SIGNING {{!}} Millers land late deal for Towell|last=|first=|date=31 August 2017|work=Rotherham United F.C.|access-date=6 July 2018|language=en-gb}} On 31 August 2018 he returned to Rotherham United for a second season-long loan spell.{{cite web|url=https://www.themillers.co.uk/news/2018/august/signing--rotherham-complete-loan-return-for-richie/#.W4kuAUaPC3o.twitter|title=SIGNING {{!}} Rotherham complete loan return for Richie|publisher=Rotherham United Official Site|date=31 August 2018}} ==International career== In May 2008, Towell made his [[Republic of Ireland national under-17 football team|Republic of Ireland under-17's]] debut in a [[UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|European championship match]] against [[Switzerland national under-17 football team|Switzerland]].{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/owngoal-agony-as-swiss-roll-ireland-in-turkey-1369398.html |title=Ireland U17 0–1 Switzerland U17 |author=Irish Independent |date=8 May 2008 |website= |publisher= |accessdate=6 January 2011}} He gained his second Ireland under-17 cap four days later, against [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]].{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/sublime-spanish-send-irish-home-without-a-point-1372822.html |title=Ireland U17 1–3 Spain U17 |author=Irish Independent |date=12 May 2008 |website= |publisher= |accessdate=6 January 2011}} Towell made two appearances for [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Republic of Ireland under-21s]] in the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification]] campaign.{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/teams/player=1906055/profile/index.html |publisher=[[UEFA]]|title=Richard Towell|accessdate=17 April 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Alexis Mac Allister | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Alexis Mac Allister | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1998|12|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[La Pampa Province|La Pampa]], Argentina | height = {{height|m=1.74}} | position = [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Argentinos Juniors]]
(on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]) | clubnumber = 10 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Social Parque | youthyears2 = | youthclubs2 = [[Argentinos Juniors]] | years1 = 2016–2019 | clubs1 = [[Argentinos Juniors]] | caps1 = 56 | goals1 = 8 | years2 = 2019– | clubs2 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2019– | clubs3 = → [[Argentinos Juniors]] (loan) | caps3 = 8 | goals3 = 1 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | club-update = 22:26, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = | medaltemplates = }} '''Alexis Mac Allister''' (born 24 December 1998) is an Argentine professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Argentinos Juniors]], on loan from [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].{{cite news|title=Alexis Mac Allister profile|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/alexis-mac-allister/468060/|accessdate=13 November 2017|work=Soccerway|date=13 November 2017}} ==Club career== Born in [[La Pampa Province|La Pampa]], Mac Allister, like his two brothers, started his career with Club Social y Deportivo Parque before joining [[Argentinos Juniors]]' youth setup.{{cite web|url=https://www.clarin.com/deportes/futbol/argentinos-juniors/dinastia-mac-allister-alexis-kevin-francis-brotes-colorados-argentinos-juniors_0_Sy_9ndn_M.html|title=La dinastía Mac Allister: Alexis, Kevin, Francis, los brotes colorados de Argentinos Juniors|trans-title=The Mac Allister dynasty: Alexis, Kevin, Francis, the red prospects of Argentinos Juniors|publisher=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]|language=es|date=6 March 2018|accessdate=15 January 2019}} He made his professional debut on 30 October 2016, coming on as a second-half [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Iván Colman]] in a 0–0 [[Primera B Nacional]] home draw against [[Central Córdoba de Santiago del Estero|Central Córdoba]].{{cite web|url=http://www.diariojornada.com.ar/173315/deportes/empataron_argentinos_juniors_y_central_cordoba_/|title=Empataron Argentinos Juniors y Central Córdoba|trans-title=Argentinos Juniors and Central Córdoba draw|publisher=Diario La Jornada|language=es|date=30 October 2016|accessdate=15 January 2019}} Mac Allister scored his first professional goal on 10 March 2017, netting his team's first in a 2–1 away loss against [[Instituto Atlético Central Córdoba|Instituto]]. He contributed with three goals in 23 appearances during [[2016–17 Primera B Nacional|his first senior campaign]], as his side achieved promotion to [[Argentine Primera División|Primera División]] as champions. He made his debut in the latter category on 9 September, starting in a 2–1 loss at [[Club Atlético Patronato|Patronato]].{{cite web|url=http://espndeportes.espn.com/futbol/cronica/_/id/493468|title=Argentinos debutó con derrota en la Superliga|trans-title=Argentinos debuted with defeat in the Superliga|publisher=[[ESPN Deportes]]|language=es|date=9 September 2017|accessdate=15 January 2019}} On 25 November 2017, Mac Allister and his two brothers played all together for the first time, in a 1–0 loss at [[San Lorenzo de Almagro|San Lorenzo]]; Alexis and Francis were starters, while Kevin came in as a substitute.{{cite web|url=https://www.ole.com.ar/futbol-primera/superliga-argentina-san-lorenzo-argentinos-hermanos-mac-allister-francis-alexis-kevin-cancha_0_SkGfxFwlz.html|title=Los (tres) hermanos sean unidos...|trans-title=(Three) brothers be united...|publisher=[[Olé (sports newspaper)|Olé]]|language=es|date=25 November 2017|accessdate=15 January 2019}} He scored his first goal in the top tier on 5 March 2018, netting the opener in a 2–0 home defeat of [[Boca Juniors]].{{cite web|url=https://www.clarin.com/deportes/futbol/argentinos-juniors-boca-superliga-horario-tv-formaciones_0_B1AhHyj_z.html|title=Boca tuvo una noche muy mala y cayó con un sólido Argentinos|trans-title=Boca had a very poor night and fell against a solid Argentinos|publisher=Clarín|language=es|date=5 March 2018|accessdate=15 January 2019}} On 24 January 2019, Mac Allister signed for [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on a four-and-a-half-year contract. As part of the deal, Mac Allister was loaned back to Argentinos Juniors for the remainder of the [[2018–19 Premier League|2018–19 Premier League season]].{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2019/january/albion-sign-argentinian-midfielder/|title=Albion sign Argentinian midfielder|website=Brighton & Hove Albion|date=24 January 2019|accessdate=24 January 2019}} ==International career== Shortly after debuting for Argentinos, Mac Allister received a call-up from [[Claudio Úbeda]] for the [[Argentina national under-20 football team|Argentina under-20s]].{{cite web|url=http://www.afa.org.ar/5916/el-semillero-de-los-mac-allister|title=El semillero de los Mac Allister|trans-title=The hotbed of the Mac Allisters|publisher=[[Argentine Football Association]]|language=es|date=13 November 2017|accessdate=13 November 2017}} ==Personal life== Mac Allister's older brothers [[Francis Mac Allister|Francis]] and [[Kevin Mac Allister|Kevin]] are also professional footballers.{{cite web|url=https://www.ole.com.ar/argentinos/triple-mac-allister-hermanos-argentinos_0_1874812593.html|title=Triple Mac|publisher=Olé|language=es|date=23 September 2017|accessdate=13 November 2017}} They are the sons of [[Carlos Mac Allister]] and nephews of [[Patricio Mac Allister]], both retired footballers. Mac Allister is of [[Scottish people|Scottish]] and [[Irish people|Irish]] descent. Some ancestors hailed from [[Fife]].{{cite news|title=Argentine football returns to its Scottihs founder|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/argentine-football-returns-to-roots-of-its-scottish-founder-1-1146916|accessdate=24 January 2019|work=The Scotsman|date=19 March 2018}} ==Career statistics==
